text.wiki:
Lille ( LEEL; French: [lil] (listen); Dutch: Rijsel [ˈrɛisəl]; Picard: Lile; West Flemish: Rysel) is a city at the northern tip of France, in French Flanders. On the Deûle River, near France's border with Belgium, it is the capital of the Hauts-de-France region, the prefecture of the Nord department, and the main city of the Métropole Européenne de Lille.
As of 2017, Lille had a population of 232,787 within its administrative limits, and Lille is the first city of the Métropole Européenne de Lille with a population of 1,146,320, making it the fourth-largest urban area in France after Paris, Lyon, and Marseille.


== History ==


=== Origins ===
Archeological digs seem to show the area as inhabited by as early as 2000 BC, most notably in the modern quartiers of Fives, Wazemmes and Vieux Lille. The original inhabitants of the region were the Gauls, such as the Menapians, the Morins, the Atrebates and the Nervians, who were followed by Germanic peoples: the Saxons, the Frisians and the Franks.
The legend of "Lydéric and Phinaert" puts the foundation of the city of Lille at 640. In the 8th century, the language of Old Low Franconian was spoken, as attested by toponymic research. Lille's Dutch name is Rijsel, which comes from ter ijsel (at the island) from Middle Dutch ijssel (“small island, islet”), calque of Old French l'Isle (“the Island”), itself from Latin Īnsula, from īnsula (“island”).
From 830 to around 910, the Vikings invaded Flanders. After the destruction caused by Normans' and the Magyars' invasion, the eastern part of the region was ruled by various local princes.
The first mention of the town dates from 1066: apud Insulam (Latin for "at the island"). It was then controlled by the County of Flanders, as were the regional cities (the Roman cities Boulogne, Arras, Cambrai as well as the Carolingian cities Valenciennes, Saint-Omer, Ghent and Bruges). The County of Flanders thus extended to the left bank of the Scheldt, one of the richest and most prosperous regions of Europe.


=== Middle Ages ===
The Carolingian duke Évrard lived in the city in the 9th century and participated in many of the day's political and military affairs. There was an important Battle of Lille in 1054.
From the 12th century, the fame of the Lille cloth fair began to grow. In 1144 Saint-Sauveur parish was formed, which would give its name to the modern-day quartier Saint-Sauveur.
The counts of Flanders, Boulogne, and Hainaut came together with England and East Frankia and tried to regain territory taken by Philip II of France following Henry II of England's death, a war that ended with the French victory at Bouvines in 1214. Infante Ferdinand, Count of Flanders was imprisoned and the county fell into dispute: it would be his wife, Jeanne, Countess of Flanders and Constantinople, who ruled the city. She was said to be well loved by the residents of Lille, who by that time numbered 10,000.
In 1225, the street performer and juggler Bertrand Cordel, doubtlessly encouraged by local lords, tried to pass himself off as Baldwin I of Constantinople (the father of Jeanne of Flanders), who had disappeared at the battle of Adrianople. He pushed the counties of Flanders and Hainaut towards sedition against Jeanne in order to recover his land. She called her cousin, Louis VIII ("The Lion"). He unmasked the imposter, whom Countess Jeanne quickly had hanged. In 1226 the king agreed to free Infante Ferdinand, Count of Flanders. Count Ferrand died in 1233, and his daughter Marie soon after. In 1235, Jeanne granted a city charter by which city governors would be chosen each All Saint's Day by four commissioners chosen by the ruler. On 6 February 1236, she founded the Countess's Hospital (Hospice Comtesse), which remains one of the most beautiful buildings in Old Lille. It was in her honour that the hospital of the Regional Medical University of Lille was named "Jeanne of Flanders Hospital" in the 20th century.
The Countess died in 1244 in the Abbey of Marquette, leaving no heirs. The rule of Flanders and Hainaut thus fell to her sister, Margaret II, Countess of Flanders, then to Margaret's son, Guy of Dampierre. Lille fell under the rule of France from 1304 to 1369, after the Franco-Flemish War (1297-1305).
The county of Flanders fell to the Duchy of Burgundy next, after the 1369 marriage of Margaret III, Countess of Flanders, and Philip the Bold, Duke of Burgundy. Lille thus became one of the three capitals of said Duchy, along with Brussels and Dijon. By 1445, Lille counted some 25,000 residents. Philip the Good, Duke of Burgundy, was even more powerful than the King of France, and made Lille an administrative and financial capital.
On 17 February 1454, one year after the taking of Constantinople by the Turks, Philip the Good organised a Pantagruelian banquet at his Lille palace, the still-celebrated "Feast of the Pheasant". There the Duke and his court undertook an oath to Christianity.
In 1477, at the death of the last duke of Burgundy, Charles the Bold, Mary of Burgundy married Maximilian of Austria, who thus became Count of Flanders.


=== Early modern era ===

The 16th and the 17th centuries were marked by a boom in the regional textile industry, the Protestant revolts and outbreaks of the plague.
Lille came under the rule of the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V in 1519. The Low Countries fell to his eldest son, Philip II of Spain, in 1555. The city remained under Spanish Habsburg rule until 1668.
Calvinism first appeared in the area in 1542, and by 1555, the authorities were taking steps to suppress that form of Protestantism. In 1566, the countryside around Lille was affected by the Iconoclastic Fury. In 1578, the Hurlus, a group of Protestant rebels, stormed the castle of the Counts of Mouscron. They were removed four months later by a Catholic Wallon regiment, and they tried several times between 1581 and 1582 to take the city of Lille, all in vain. The Hurlus were notably held back by the legendary Jeanne Maillotte. At the same time (1581), at the call of Elizabeth I of England, the north of the Seventeen Provinces, having gained a Protestant majority, successfully revolted and formed the Dutch Republic. The war brought or exacerbated periods of famine and plague (the last in 1667–1679).The first printer to set up shop in Lille was Antoine Tack in 1594. The 17th century saw the building of new institutions: an Irish College in 1610, a Jesuit college in 1611, an Augustinian college in 1622, almshouses or hospitals such as the Maison des Vieux hommes in 1624 and the Bonne et Forte Maison des Pauvres in 1661, and of a Mont-de-piété in 1626.Unsuccessful French attacks on the city were launched in 1641 and 1645. In 1667, Louis XIV of France (the Sun King) successfully laid siege to Lille, resulting in it becoming French in 1668 under the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle, provoking discontent among the citizens of the prosperous city. A number of important public works undertaken between 1667 and 1670, such as the Citadel (erected by Vauban), or the creation of the quartiers of Saint-André and la Madeleine, enabled the French king to gradually gain the confidence of his new subjects in Lille, some of whom continued to feel Flemish, but they had always spoken the Romance Picard language.

For five years, from 1708 to 1713, the city was occupied by the Dutch during the War of the Spanish Succession. Throughout the 18th century, Lille remained profoundly Catholic. It took little part in the French Revolution, but there were riots and the destruction of churches. In 1790, the city held its first municipal elections.


=== Post-French Revolution ===
In 1792, in the aftermath of the French Revolution, the Austrians, then in the United Provinces, laid siege to Lille. The "Column of the Goddess", erected in 1842 in the "Grand-Place" (officially named Place du Général-de-Gaulle), is a tribute to the city's resistance, led by Mayor François André-Bonte. Although Austrian artillery destroyed many houses and the main church of the city, the city did not surrender, and the Austrian Army left after eight days.

The city continued to grow and, by 1800, had some 53,000 residents, leading to Lille becoming the seat of the Nord départment in 1804. In 1846, a railway connecting Paris and Lille was built. In the early the 19th century, Napoleon I's continental blockade against the United Kingdom led to Lille's textile industry developing even more fully. The city was known for its cotton while the nearby towns of Roubaix and Tourcoing worked wool.  Leisure activities were thoroughly organised in 1858 for the 80,000 inhabitants.  Cabarets or taverns for the working class numbered 1,300, or one for every three houses. At that time the city counted 63 drinking and singing clubs, 37 clubs for card players, 23 for bowling, 13 for skittles, and 18 for archery. The churches likewise have their social organizations. Each club had a long roster of officers, and a busy schedule of banquets festivals and competitions. In 1853, Alexandre Desrousseaux composed his lullaby P'tit quinquin.
In 1858, Lille annexed the adjacent towns of Fives, Wazemmes, and Moulins. Lille's population was 158,000 in 1872, growing to over 200,000 by 1891. In 1896 Lille became the first city in France to be led by a socialist, Gustave Delory.
By 1912, Lille's population stood at 217,000. The city profited from the Industrial Revolution, particularly via coal and the steam engine. The entire region grew wealthy thanks to its mines and textile industry.


=== First World War ===

Lille's occupation by the Germans began on 13 October 1914 after a ten-day siege and heavy shelling, which destroyed 882 apartment and office blocks and 1,500 houses, mostly around the railway station and in the centre. By the end of October, the city was being run by German authorities.
Because Lille was only 20 km from the battlefield, German troops passed through the city regularly on their way to and from the front. As a result, occupied Lille became a place for the hospitalisation and the treatment of wounded soldiers as well as a place for soldiers' relaxation and entertainment. Many buildings, homes and businesses were requisitioned to those ends.Lille was liberated by the Allies on 17 October 1918, when General Sir William Birdwood and his troops were welcomed by joyous crowds. The general was made an honorary citizen of the city of Lille on 28 October.
The only audio recording known to have been made during World War I was recorded near Lille in October 1918. The two-minute recording captured the Royal Garrison Artillery conducting a gas shell bombardment.Lille was also the hunting ground of the German World War I flying ace Max Immelmann, who was nicknamed "the Eagle of Lille".


=== Années Folles, Great Depression and Popular Front ===

In July 1921, at the Pasteur Institute in Lille, Albert Calmette and Camille Guérin discovered the first anti-tuberculosis vaccine, known as BCG ("Bacille de Calmette et Guérin"). The Opéra de Lille, designed by Lille architect Louis M. Cordonnier, was dedicated in 1923.
From 1931, Lille felt the repercussions of the Great Depression, and by 1935, a third of the city's population lived in poverty. In 1936, the city's mayor, Roger Salengro, became Minister of the Interior of the Popular Front but eventually killed himself after right-wing groups led a slanderous campaign against him.


=== Second World War ===

During the Battle of France, Lille was besieged by German forces for several days. When Belgium was invaded, the citizens of Lille, still haunted by the events of World War I, began to flee the city in large numbers. Lille was part of the zone under control of the German commander in Brussels, and was never controlled by the Vichy government in France. Lille was instead controlled under the military administration in Northern France. The départments of Nord and Pas-de-Calais (with the exception of the coast, notably Dunkirk) were for the most part liberated from 1 to 5 September 1944, by British, Canadian and Polish troops. On 3 September, German troops began to leave Lille out of fear of the British, who were on their way from Brussels. The city was liberated by a British force consisting largely of tanks.Rationing came to an end in 1947, and by 1948, normality had returned to Lille.


=== Postwar ===

In 1967, the Chambers of Commerce of Lille, Roubaix and Tourcoing were joined, and in 1969< the Communauté urbaine de Lille (Lille urban community) was created, linking 87 communes with Lille.
Throughout the 1960s and the 1970s, the region was faced with some problems after the decline of the coal, mining and textile industries. From the early 1980s, the city began to turn itself more towards the service sector.
In 1983, the VAL, the world's first automated rapid transit underground network, opened. In 1993, a high-speed TGV train line was opened connecting Paris with Lille in one hour. This, with the opening of the Channel Tunnel in 1994 and the arrival of the Eurostar train put Lille at the centre of a triangle connecting Paris, London and Brussels.
Work on Euralille, an urban remodelling project, began in 1991. The Euralille Centre was opened in 1994, and the remodeled district is now full of parks and modern buildings containing offices, shops and apartments. In 1994 the "Grand Palais" was also opened for the general public, which is free for the public to enter on the first Sunday of every month.
Lille was chosen as European Capital of Culture in 2004, along with the Italian city of Genoa.
Lille and Roubaix were affected by the 2005 riots, like all of France's other urban centres.
In 2007 and again in 2010, Lille was awarded the label "Internet City".


== Climate ==
Lille can be described as having a temperate oceanic climate; summers normally do not reach high average temperatures, but winters can fall below freezing temperatures, but with averages quite a bit above the freezing mark. Precipitation is plentiful year round.
The table below gives average temperatures and precipitation levels for the 1981-2010 reference period.


== Environment ==
Lille is noted for its air pollution, with a 2018 study attributing 1,700 deaths per year in the agglomeration of Lille to pollution. In 2018, Lille held France's record pollution peaks.


== Economy ==

A former major mechanical, food industry and textile manufacturing centre as well as a retail and finance center, Lille is the largest city of a conurbation, built like a network of cities: Lille, Roubaix, Tourcoing and Villeneuve d'Ascq. The conurbation forms the Métropole Européenne de Lille which is France's fourth-largest urban conglomeration with a 2016 population of over 1.15 million.


=== Revenues and taxes ===
For centuries, Lille, a city of merchants, has displayed a wide range of incomes: great wealth and poverty have lived side by side, especially until the end of the 1800s. This contrast was noted by Victor Hugo in 1851 in his poem Les Châtiments:  « Caves de Lille ! on meurt sous vos plafonds de pierre ! » ("Cellars of Lille! We die under your stone ceilings!")


=== Employment ===
Employment in Lille has switched over half a century from a predominant industry to tertiary activities and services.
Services account for 91% of employment in 2006.

Employment in Lille-Hellemmes-Lomme from 1968 to 2006

Employment per categories in 1968 and in 2006

Unemployment in active population from 1968 to 2006


=== Enterprises ===
In 2007, Lille hosts around 21,000 industry or service sites.

Enterprises as per 31 December 2007


== Main sights ==
Lille features an array of architectural styles with various amounts of Flemish influence, including the use of brown and red brick. In addition, many residential neighborhoods, especially in Greater Lille, consist of attached 2–3 story houses aligned in a row, with narrow gardens in the back. These architectural attributes, many uncommon in France, help make Lille a transition in France to neighboring Belgium, as well as nearby Netherlands and England, where the presence of brick, as well as row houses or the terraced house is much more prominent.
Points of interest include

Lille Cathedral (Basilique-cathédrale Notre-Dame-de-la-Treille)
Citadel of Lille
Palais des Beaux-Arts de Lille
Jardin botanique de la Faculté de Pharmacie
Jardin botanique Nicolas Boulay
Jardin des Plantes de Lille


=== La Braderie ===

Lille hosts an annual braderie on the first weekend in September. Its origins are thought to date back to the twelfth century and between two and three million visitors are drawn into the city. It is one of the largest gatherings of France and the largest flea market in Europe.
Many of the roads in the inner city (including much of the old town) are closed and local shops, residents and traders set up stalls in the street.


== Gallery ==

		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		


== Transport ==


=== Public transport ===

The Métropole Européenne de Lille has a mixed mode public transport system, which is considered one of the most modern in the whole of France. It comprises buses, trams and a driverless light metro system, all of which are operated under the Transpole name. The Lille Metro is a VAL system (véhicule automatique léger = light automated vehicle) that opened on 16 May 1983, becoming the first automatic light metro line in the world. The system has two lines, with a total length of 45 kilometres (28 miles) and 60 stations. The tram system consists of two interurban tram lines, connecting central Lille to the nearby communities of Roubaix and Tourcoing, and has 45 stops. 68 urban bus routes cover the metropolis, 8 of which reach into Belgium.


=== Railways ===

Lille is an important crossroads in the European high-speed rail network. It lies on the Eurostar line to London (1:20 hour journey). The French TGV network also puts it only 1 hour from Paris, 38 minutes from Brussels, and connects to other major centres in France such as Marseille, Lyon, and Toulouse. Lille has two railway stations, which stand next door to one another: Lille-Europe station (Gare de Lille-Europe), which primarily serves high-speed trains and international services (Eurostar), and Lille-Flandres station (Gare de Lille-Flandres), which primarily serves lower speed regional trains and regional Belgian trains.


=== Highways ===

Five autoroutes pass by Lille, the densest confluence of highways in France after Paris:

Autoroute A27 : Lille – Tournai – Brussels / Liège – Germany
Autoroute A23 : Lille – Valenciennes
Autoroute A1  : Lille – Arras – Paris / Reims – Lyon / Orléans / Le Havre
Autoroute A25 : Lille – Dunkirk – Calais – England / North Belgium
Autoroute A22 : Lille – Antwerp – NetherlandsA sixth one – the proposed A24 – will link Amiens to Lille if built, but there is opposition to its route.


=== Air traffic ===
Lille Lesquin International Airport is 15 minutes from the city centre by car (11 km). In terms of shipping, it ranks fourth, with almost 38,000 tonnes of freight which pass through each year. Its passenger traffic, around 1.2 million in 2010, is modest due to the proximity to Brussels, Charleroi, and Paris-CDG airports. The airport mostly connects other French and European cities (some with low-cost airlines).


=== Waterways ===

Lille is the third-largest French river port after Paris and Strasbourg. The river Deûle is connected to regional waterways with over 680 km (423 mi) of navigable waters. The Deûle connects to Northern Europe via the River Scarpe and the River Scheldt (towards Belgium and the Netherlands), and internationally via the Lys River (to Dunkerque and Calais).
Shipping statistics


== Education ==
With over 110,000 students, the metropolitan area of Lille is one of France's top student cities.

With roots back from 1562 to 1793 as University of Douai, (then as Université Impériale in 1808), the State University of Lille was established in Lille in 1854 with Louis Pasteur as the first dean of its Faculty of Sciences. A school of medicine and an engineering school were also established in Lille in 1854; and the University of Lille was united as the association of existing public Faculties in 1896. It was then split into three independent university campuses in 1970: Lille 1 University of Science and Technology, Lille 2 University of Law and Health, and Lille 3 Charles de Gaulle University of Humanities, Social sciences, Literature and Arts.At the beginning of 2018, Lille 1, Lille 2 and Lille 3 merged to form the new University of Lille (student enrollment: 70,000).
It is part of the Community of Universities and Institutions (COMUE) Lille Nord de France and the European Doctoral College Lille Nord de France.

The Arts et Métiers ParisTech, an engineering graduate school of industrial and mechanical engineering, settled in Lille in 1900. This campus is one of the eight Teaching and Research Center (CER) of the school. Its creation was decided by Pierre-Nicolas Legrand de Lérant.
Ecole Centrale de Lille is one of the five Centrale Graduate Schools of engineering in France; it was founded in Lille city in 1854, its graduate engineering education and research center was established as Institut industriel du Nord (IDN) in 1872, in 1968 it moved in a modern campus in Lille suburb.
École nationale supérieure de chimie de Lille was established as Institut de chimie de Lille in 1894 supporting chemistry research as followers of Kuhlmann's breakthrough works in Lille.
École supérieure de journalisme de Lille, journalism school created in 1924.
Skema Business School established in 1892 is ranked among the top business schools in France.
École pour l'informatique et les nouvelles technologies settled in Lille in 2009.
ESME-Sudria and E-Artsup settled in Lille in 2012.
The ESA – École Supérieure des Affaires is a Business Management school established in Lille in 1990.
IEP Sciences-Po Lille political studies institute was established in Lille in 1992.
The Institut supérieur européen de formation par l'action is also located in Lille.
The Institut supérieur européen de gestion group (ISEG Group) established in Lille in 1988.
The European Doctoral College Lille Nord de France is headquartered in Lille Metropolis and includes 3,000 PhD Doctorate students supported by university research laboratories.
The Université Catholique de Lille was founded in 1875. Today it has law, economics, medicine, physics faculties and schools. Among the most famous is Institut catholique d'arts et métiers (ICAM) founded in 1898, ranked 20th among engineering schools, with the specificity of graduating polyvalent engineers, Ecole des Hautes études d'ingénieur (HEI) a school of engineering founded in 1885 and offering 10 fields of specialization, École des hautes études commerciales du nord (EDHEC) founded in 1906, IESEG School of Management founded in 1964 (17th place in the latest Financial Times global ranking of the 90 best masters in management, published on Monday 12 September 2016).  and Skema Business School currently ranked within the top 5, the top 10 and top 15 business schools in France, respectively. In 1924 ESJ – a leading journalism school – was established.


== Notable people from Lille ==


=== Writers ===
Jacquemart Giélée (13th century), poet
Yvonne Chauffin (1905–1995), writer, winner of the 1970 edition of the Prix Breizh
Jean Prieur (1914–2008), writer and professor

=== Sportspeople ===


== Media and sports ==
Local newspapers include Nord éclair and La Voix du Nord.
France's national public television network has a channel that focuses on the local area: France 3 Nord-Pas-de-Calais
The city's most major association football club, Lille OSC, currently plays in Ligue 1, the highest level of football in France. The club has won eight major national trophies and regularly features in the UEFA Champions League and UEFA Europa League. In the 2010–11 season, Lille won the league and cup double.
Lille's Stade Pierre-Mauroy was the playground for the final stages of the FIBA EuroBasket 2015.
It was in Lille that the 100th World Esperanto Congress took place, in 2015.

text.quote: Ornate 17th-century Renaissance stock exchange, with campanile with gold Mercury statue & courtyard.
trip: This is an impressive building on the big square in the center of town. As we had lunch near here we had quite a bit of time to admire its majesty. It will be on your tour.

This is a magnificent, opulent building that wreaks of old money. The details in the facades, the lead work to the most complicated of roofs and the crisp state of repair. This is quality and well worth inspection. Please spare the time to stand back and look up.
Marvelous building dominating the main square of the old city. Amazing architecture and details, both on exterior and in the courtyard.

beautiful building in center Lille, well worth to check out and visit. i inside the patio you will find romantic set of booksellers with all kinds of second hand books for sale. just pure nostalgia and romance

This building was a treat to visit! The outside was beautiful and the inside housed a lot of booksellers!
Beautiful building inside and out. Interesting book market full of books, stamps, posters etc. Nice atmosphere .

What a beautiful old building, stunning architecture & painting, just breathtaking. Loved the way it opens out into a square in the centre, surrounded by arches & infilled by little old book & artefact sellers. Just couldn’t stop looking up at it all. So beautiful. Surreal.
Really attractive old building that hosts a secondhand book market during the afternoons. So definitely worth a visit to rummage through the old books and take a few photos.
The redundant building is worth a visit to see the lovely architecture and have a browse amongst the books and bric a brac that now own the space. You might find a treasure!
Worth a quick walk through its courtyard to see the attention to detail hidden in this attractive building. Try and catch up with its history to appreciate more what is in front of you.
Part of the charming Vieux Lille centre, this is a lovely old building and one of the must-see sights as you visit the city.

There are floh markt inside worth to visit. Originally it was stock market bulilding. The story of the bulilding and the 24 small houses are very pretty and unique. From the middle of the inside thereis a missing statue.
What a great building. The old stock exchange with its open quad is a fantastic old building. The mirror stars hanging down are great and the book stalls are fantastic.
Beautiful old stock exchange building, now a market with second hand book stores, posters etc surrounded by cafes and bars. Lovely place to sit outside and wat h the world go by.

Ancient stock exchange. In the courtyard are many second hand book, pamphlet, poster dealers; some stuff in other languages - all very cheap. But then look at the building, and if you have time decipher the plaques around the insied walls of all the notable lLilleous
Very attractive building with secondhand book sales and chess ongoing. Interesting art works. Lovely colours
Lots of history and very beautiful, definitely recommend and super postcards and old books and art. A little bit touristy but it is very nice overall.
Lovely architecture, we visited on a Saturday where they had a second hand book and poster market. Beautifully preserved. Busy but we were there on a Saturday.

Lille has a very charming old town, with a lot of lovely buildings. This one is one of those and it is worth to visit. On Saturdays, they host a fair (books, records, etc) and on a sunny day, makes the visit to Lille more interesting.
Well worth a look and looking at all the medallions of famous people celebrated on the upper inner courtyard.

Lille is a lovely town. Not as expensive as Paris. I only stayed a couple of days and the weather wasn't good but I would like to visit when the weather is better. There was so much I didn't get to see.
It's hard not to notice this building, with its almost hidden courtyard with venders selling old books, magazines and posters. Worth a visit for a few minutes or a perusal if you can read french!
This is well worth a look inside the courtyard as there's a book market held in the afternoon. The architecture is stunning.
A special site now used for selling second-hand books but with all the charm preserved from history.
When in Lille, visit this place. Authentic, nice. It is one of the main histrocial building of Lille. You can discover it in family.
A lovely building in the main square cannot miss it. Worth a quick trip inside for second hand books or retro goods.

For starters, it's a lovely building. Then inside, if you go at the wrong time of day, it's just a dusty, dull old shell. Go at the right time though, and you can spend an hour rummaging through boxes of books, posters and old plastic toys. A brilliant way to spend some time.
Worth a quick visit. Lovely architecture and in the courtyard inside is a secondhanded book market, which also sells magazines, annuals, records etc. Offers good shelter from the rain!.

This is a lovely building and shows great architecture. However it takes about 10 minutes to look round and there is nothing extra ordinary to do or see. It now has a market within selling mainly French tat!!
This building has a central courtyard, surrounded by a "cloisters" in which stalls selling books, posters etc are set up. Beautiful setting.

As you look around in the center of town this is the first building that you notice. Yes, any reference to Lille will include pictures of the Old Stock Exchange, the structure in real life is truly impressive.

Build when Lille was part of Spain, as a partially covered market inside and shops with apartments upstairs on the outside. Currently, nobody lives here anymore, but the shops are still there, and the cloth markets has been converted into a 2nd hand book market under high
Beautiful building, a must see in Lille. Used as a market that mainly sells old books. Opens at 1 pm.

During the daytime this is an interesting building with a market in the courtyard. On the Saturday night when we were there there was a huge free party in the middle with salsa music lots of dancing and a really good party vibe. Lots of people all age groups and abilities it was

A handsome old stock exchange - one of the most distinguished buildings in Lille - entrances in the Place du General de Gaulle & Place du Theatre - most afternoons the cloisters inside are filled with second hand & antiquarian booksellers - a must see in Lille! Free!

Interesting architecture but not much else to see except a second hand book market when we visited, although I believe the interior courtyard is used for a range of events Nonetheless worth a quick look if you're in the area

The Old Stock Exchange Building is now home to bars, cafes, restaurants and other shops. Situated on the corner of the Grand Place, the building is imposing. The building is well maintained and the shields just below the roof line are one of the better features. A good meeting

What a great space inside this building. Beautiful carvings all around and even the drain pipes have fish heads at their bases. There was a book/flea market inside when we went during the day and a salsa dancing event during the evening. Fabulous to watch everyone enjoying the
This is a lovely ornate building where you can enter for freen you walk around the outside as well as enter the inside.

One of the beautiful grand buildings on one of the main squares. The outside looks great, indied is a courtyard where people sell all sorts of second hand stuff etc. Entrance to this is free. You cannot get inside the building itself though.

This was by far the most favourite building I saw in our entire European trip. Lille itself is a very quaint small town - lots of shops & restaurants. University city so has lots going on. We did a historical walking tour which was very interesting (there are many beautiful

We decided to visit Lille and the Grand Place old town. It is a quaint open area surrounded by beautiful buildings. The most beautiful building of all was the Old Stock Exchange. Majestic and restored, the center square is worth going to for this building alone. Beautiful!
Stunning g building outside and inside. Have a good rummage through the books and artwork. You never know what you will find....one of my favorite buildings in Lille.
Just off the main square. It is a lively old building with lots of information and some stalls. A lovely little place to browse and enjoy some shade. I recommend a look!!

A nice building located on the Grand Place. Make sure that you don’t go early morning as you will not be able to get into the inner courtyard as the gates will be locked. This is a trading area so leave till after the shops have opened.
Stopped by during our morning walk but unfortunately, the inner courtyard was closed. We still took some nice photos of the outside.

The building, or collection of buildings actually, is stunning to look at on the outside. I went back in the afternoon when you can enter the courtyard where the used book sale is set up, and realized that the walls and doorways also have painting and inscriptions. Very neat.

This building in an architectural gem. I really enjoyed my short visit here. Check the hours to be sure you can see the interior courtyard. There was an awesome vendor selling French antique newspapers inside with lovely illustrations on them (early 1900s). I can't wait to go
Very historic old exchange with interesting architectural features and quaint little stalls selling old knick knacks, posters and the like. Chess game knockout in the middle.

Always enjoy a visit to the Vielle Bourse market. Walk round and browse for hours. Stall holders do have a very inflated idea of value though. Fantastic building with great detailing. Check out the downspout ends in the corners.

Wecwere very impressed by the exterior of this wonderful building . Walked into the interior courtyard to find it is ever more impressive from that view point. While tours of the building were not offered when we visited we did walk up the stair to look around. In the
It was closed at lunch but went back in the afternoon. Beautiful building with courtyard. Lots of antiques, books, records, posters etc.
A lovely and historical place to check second hand books. You can find nice books and take good pictures there.

Wasn’t sure what this was until looking at TA. In the square next to La Place. Beautiful building with the most amazing architecture. Well,worth a visit but not sure about entry times. Nice just to sit & look at the building with a glass of rose in hand!

Lovely place to wander through - browse books, magazines and vinyls if you will, or just enjoy the atmosphere of this old square. You can walk through to the others side, to arrive at the Grand Place. A short visit for most people, - a nice addition to a walk about the area.

This place is not only interesting for visit and buy some old books and magazines but also unique ace for photos. Last few months I went from time to time to take some photos of people in the market. Worth visiting!!

People enter, not looking for anything, start looking, then keep looking. What they are searching for, they do not know and it does not really matter. Keeping looking up is what matters. Some people might find what they were not looking for. Most wont and again, it does not

The old bourse building is on the side of the Place Charles de Gaulle. You can’t miss it, in is a Flemish architectural extravaganza covered in ornate French! In the courtyard there is a used book market and other antiques including maps, pictures and china. The building

Amazing building and can imagine the hustle and bustle of the past. Great to see and feel the environment. If there's an opportunity, take a seat... It appeared there may be a market but wasn't running on our visit.

We were just wandering through and there were vendors selling books from the 1700-1800s, vintage advertisements from the turn of the century, antique dishes and furniture. We only made it as far as the courtyard and spent hours flipping through books and advertisements like it

This is basically a building with large internal courtyard which holds a book and poster art market in the cloister area. Worth a walk around but also if you go into one of the independent cafes accessed from outside the building,ding they have retained some of the old spiral

Built under Spanish rule in 1653, the former stock exchange is a beautiful example of Flemish Renaissance architecture. Make sure to walk into the interior courtyard with its beautiful colonnade and enjoy the book market and old men playing chess.
The building is stunning and well kept. Inside is a beautiful open air atrium with market stalls selling posters and second hand books.
Treasures all over, hidden gems, bric a brace, posters, postcards, glasses, tea sets, books and magazines .... in the fantastic courtyard with gorgeous architecture.

The courtyard area is packed full of second-hand bookseller’s tables stacked high with old newspaper clippings and novels. The actual building is found at the Grand Place, Lille city centre and is highly impressive and only a stone’s throw from the Column of the Goddess (La
Typical for this city very nice building with big free space in it, where people sell books and newspapers. Make mood of city
Great architecture with a mini ice-rink with glittering lights making it a festive treat. The rink was surrounded with little local stalls selling food, clothing and other knick knacks
What a delight to find the old Bourse filled with stalls containing used books, old periodicals, antique prints and vintage toys.
It's everything the guide books say: Fantastic features, ancient books, maps and posters. Correct right down to the chess players.

The Vielle Bourse is a very interesting-looking building from the outside. However when we visited it was not possible to see the 24 houses set around the interior courtyard as the inside of the building was closed for restoration.
We were walking in Lille and saw this old building and enjoyed the ice skating arena and as well as book stores, recommending to go.
Worth to spend the time to visit this old building.There have second-hand stuff and books for sale.very interesting! When you visit Old Stock Exchange, just be slow down and enjoy French tempo.
One of the nicest buildings in town. Well worth a walk around and through the courtyard to admire the architecture and the way the structure has been so well maintained.
Another lovely example of the very pretty architecture Lille has to offer Went on a lovely winters day so colours really stood out in the light.

A lovely old building externally and with a charming courtyard inside. While you can't go inside, the booksellers and occasional artist that now seem to be permanently in the courtyard are worth a few minutes of your time. Perusing the old books and magazines is useful to

This place is just off Grand Place. We went in when there was a little market going on. I am not sure how frequently this happens (we went on a Saturday afternoon). There were loads of little things to buy - it's more like car boot sale kind of stuff. Lovely atmosphere and nice
An attractive court yard building now enjoyed by artists and book sellers to offer their wares. The environment is artisan and also stimulating to the mind. An experience in a less modern world.
You can go inside to the market, which allows you to see the interior of the building - beautiful architecture and worth a closer look.

Lille's old town is filled with lovely old buildings. I chanced upon the Stock Exchange as I was exploring the town. I actually didn't know it was open but I came upon a door and walked in. It was an old courtyard inside. there were people playing chess and there were old books

We didn't know it was open to visit so when we saw an open door we got in ;) The courtyard was full of goods (books, comics, goblets and God only know what else!) and very polite sellers behind their goods ready to trade. Enjoy this atmosphere of commerce where time seems stopped
Beautiful old building certainly one of the most impressive in this very pretty city,well worth checking it out.

Effectively an old courtyard where traders sell old magazines, postcards, posters etc. A bit of a flea market. Building itself is fascinating, old and quaint but there are lots like it around northern Europe
Old beautiful building with atrium inside where you can buy old books or posters. This building is must see in Lille.

The old stock exchange is beautifully constructed. Before entering the courtyard, there are restaurants around it. You'll find old and relatively new book sellers. There's one that sells antiques, old postcards, glassware, coins, foreign bank notes (for collectors). Another

The building is really very nice and full of historical details that you can read under the entrance porche. There are book stores and antiques stalls in the middle. Make sure you visit this place when going to Lille.
Beautiful building, even the courtyard. Whilst all the books are French it is still very atmospheric.
Well worth a look inside if you have 15 minutes spare, especially to see the ornate decoration in the main hall.

The old stock exchange has an interesting story with the coats of Arms, height requirement, etc. I thought it was funny that the back side has an allege steeple that exceeded the King's specifications!
This is a very beautiful historic building and you can walk through the centre of it. When we were here there was a vintage market inside selling a wide variety of collectables.

wanneer je de oude beurs binnen loopt waan je je in oudere tijden. Herleef de tijd dat hier gehandeld werd en overlegd. When you enter the old stock exchange you feel the atmosphere of ancient time, in that people were trading goods
Centre of town full of old retro posters and old books great place for a walk. Found some interesting books and plenty of historic literature something you tend to find Ina boot sale.
This building is so nice and has a rich history behind it also has some nice little market stalls inside and little coffee shops around it
besides the beauty of the building both from inside and outside, there are old posters, vinyl and many other interesting old stuff are sold inside
Now you can find art and book sold inside and it is centrally located so you can't miss it. Quite beautiful building!

The old stock exchange is a famous monumental building that is build of 24 identical houses. Theres a small courtyard inside the building where there can be a market going on, mostly books but also sometimes antiques. At the top of the bell tower theres a statue of Mercury, the
This is a lovely building with some interesting history. There is an antiques market inside mostly selling old magazines and old collectables. Many of the stalls appear to be closed during the week.
Its located in the central in the same area with Grand Place (in front of it). I did not enter the building but from outside it looked beautiful.

An attractive building hiding an interesting courtyard. There was a large stall with items for collectors - glass, brass, pewter,ceramics, metal work and maps, old weeklymagazines etc. That was the only stall open at lunch time but later in the afternoon several bouquinistes
We went in as part of a guided tour which was great as we learned about the building and history. Apparently in the summer they hold Tango dances in the courtyard which I am sure must be great.

The old stock exchange building is attractive from the outside, located between two of the main squares in central Lille, facing the Opera across the place du Theatre and the Theatre du Nord across the place de Ch. de Gaulle. Unlike most of the older buildings you can freely go
Lovely building and the internal square is now being used to sell old books. Well worth 20 mins to have a look and maybe buy an old poster etc.

It's an impressive looking building but nothing more. We had a cup of coffee in one of the shops on the ground floor. I wasn't aware there was anything more to it or you could get in, similar to most if this area it's not signposted.

My favourite building in the city. Important for economical reasons in the past, now it is foundamental for touristic reasons. Flemish in the style, it's a building that you cannot just ignore. Get inside and visit the fairs often organized inside and spend some of your time

La Vieille Bourse, the former commercial exchange of Lille, is not only a stunning building, it is also a delightful place. From the outside, it looks like a single building but it is in fact composed of 24 identical houses built around a beautiful arcaded courtyard with slender

Dominates the picturesque town square. The open air internal square now used as a flea market of mainly books, posters and bric a brac. Unless you are there to study the architecture the visit will not need more than 10 minutes plus any browsing time of the flea market.
very nice place. You fell like you came back to Medieval era and everything around is historic and expressive.

The old stock exchange building is fascinating. It is run down and presently used as a casual market place for local items such as used books but it is a very impressive building and well worth a look.

In the Place du theatre are several splendid old buildings but the Old Bourse - La Vielle Bourse - is a collection of twenty-four identical historical tiny multi-story houses clustered around a square. The exterior view is lovely - but the interior, with stalls selling old

Lovely building. You can enter into the courtyard. There often seems to be something going on. The first time we went in there was a flea market. On Sunday evening, a tango evening - locals dancing the tango. A lovely sight and beautiful to watch (Sunday evenings in July, August

when staying in Lille and walking around, the building of the old stock exchange can not be avoided. This ancient building certainly has its historical value and you should walk through. It is certainly not a top location.
It is worth going inside to the centre square to check it out! Tons of history! Beautiful old building!

a wonderful old book market with fantastic old illustrated papers going back to the beginning of the 20th century and tracing the lead up to both 1st and 2nd world wars as well as fashion of the times. No books in English sadly.

while in area, noticed people walking through the arch, so we followed, you walk in the open inner courtyard, where a few stalls where set up selling old books, maps, well worth having a look around.....never entered the building itself but the building looks great, they knew
There was a small market section on the Sunday morning but later on when we passed by there was a lovely dance performance going on. Quaint!

We visited Lille for the Euro Championships and on the day Wales were playing Belguim the city was bursting at the seams. As we walked through the square, one second we were in the middle of a crowd singing and the next we were in the Old Stock Exchange in the quiet and
Lovely outside and within the inner courtyard, now a market for books et al. 10 minutes plus book browsing time

A magnificent building adjacent to the Opera House, the old Bourse now has stalls selling old books, prints and maps. Well worth a browse to look around the courtyard or to see what bargains are on display. A constructive use for a now redundant building.

The Old Bourse is situated in the central historic part of Lille adjacent to the Theatre and Chambers of Commerce. The building is strikingly beautiful and typical of the historic architecture of Northern France and Belgium (Flanders). Inside there is a book, painting and art

This fine old building in the centre of Lille has been maintained to a very high level. There are a number of small businesses on the ground level and a nice courtyard inside with numerous stalls. Well worth a visit.
There are some flea market type sellers in the middle of the courtyard of the building. It's a beautiful example of the mid 17th century architecture.
The inner yard is filled with stalls selling all sorts of posters, books, comic books, old maps - I could spend hours there, and the decor is so pretty!

Never been on a guided tour. Nice well kept old building. Inside open so you can get wet. Lots of old & new books, minor collectibles, old magazines and coins. Never been above the ground floor. Don't know if you can. unless you are a real book buff you canget round it in under

This attraction was on our list of must-sees, but it did not open until mid afternoon which meant that we did not have enough time there before catching the Eurostar back to London. The architecture was good, particularly on the outside of the building. Inside, there were

Go on a walking tour bookable at the tourist information office, itself an interesting building, to learn more about the marvellous old stock exchange and who lived there. In the Summer they dance the Tango here!
A place to visit for its history both inside and out and for its contents....the books, posters magazines and curios are well worth a look
A very historic courtyard with alcoves and many booksellers. Sadly the weather was so wet and cold only a few brave souls were out.

This building is incredible to look at from the outside but also amazing on the inside. Most days, they have a small book market inside, so you can go in and admire all the arches and the beautiful architectural details. It's right across the grand place and near the opera. You

La Vieille Bourse is a sriking building in the centre of Lille and is located between Grand Place and Place du Théâtre. It was designed by Julien Destrée and was completed in 1653 and is highly decorative and is in keeping with the many attractive buildings in the city.
It's a lovely building that hosted a vintage market when we were there. It's nice to see and worth the 5min walk from the train station.
Very nice interior of the old stock exchange, good for architectural lovers. Also very nice, are the book sales taking place inside. This is mainly for old books. I would definitely go there again!
On of the nicest and oldest building of Lille, next to the "grand'Place" , and close to the "vieux lille" quarter. ( find nice bars behind ;-) )
Nice, old building. Worth a visit. On the day we went to Lille (a Saturday) there were some merchants inside, selling some second hand stuff.
Part of the old town. Interesting exterior and interior. If you are in the old town you will pass it but go inside too.

We loved the courtyard setting of this secondhand bookmarket - search on the web to find opening hours. As well as books, there are plenty of DVDs and posters and some stalls selling small 'brocante' stuff like glasses, keyrings and corkscrews. Very French somehow and an
Stunning architecture. Inside courtyard used by traders selling second hand books, records etc. Not able to go inside the building which was a great shame.
The building is a must in grand place, well conserved with an interesting architecture. The pátio interior sometimes has a second hand books seling. A must see.

The stock exchange is a striking building on the Grand Place, which connects to the Place du theatre. The building itself is impressive, although around the bottom it is home to cafes and small businesses now. It doesn't seem that you can explore the interior of the building at

Supposedly the place to be for booklovers, well the trip to fnac was more inspiring! There weren't a heck of a lot of vendors, maybe five and the merchandise consisted of kitsch vinyl albums, knickknacks, old styled wine or liquor glasses and cheesy paperback pockets,comic

Easily accessed as it is just opposite the opera house and next to the Grand Place this is the old exchange building made up of what were some 24 different traders' lodgings during the week this is the equivalent of the bouquinistes selling books etc along the Seine in Paris. On

A brilliant building to check out in the middle of Lille. Inside there is also a book market and some art works sold which is quite a wonderful use of space in the Old Stock Exchange! This is an excellent place for photographers.
This is a lovely building. very clean impressive looking,but old. Unfortunately the day we were there scaffolding was up and could not look inside the building.

A lovely building on the Grand Place, worth a look-in but I'm afraid it is just a building with cafés on the outside and a 'flea' type market on the inside. OK so it is free to walk through - which is what we did. And came out safely the other side a few minutes later. Or have I

The Old Stock Exchange in Lille was without a doubt one of the most staggeringly beautiful buildings I have ever seen. It is steeped in history. The façade itself is absolutely amazing... and that's just the outside! The inside opens up into a whole new world! There is a mini

The Old Stock Exchange is one of the iconic Flemish buildings in the centre of Lille. The shop around the outside are high end boutiques and bars, but when we went inside there was a small antiques fair. The fair was brilliant selling a real assortment of unusual antiques. We
Lovely outside building. Didn't get to. Go in, as was being renovated when I went but lovely to admire.
A very historical and unique piece of architecture. Just next to the city center. It's a must if you're in town. Check it out the walls inside the building.

By day, this interesting old building's square interior houses many stalls selling antiques and books. You may also watch mature gentlemen playing chess. On Sunday nights it is transformed into a tango extravaganza. Numerous couples of all ages gather to tango the night away. It
A nice piece of history in the center of the city surrounded with cafes and next to Christmas market. Inside you can buy new and old books.
Walked through the inner courtyard where they had second hand books, toys, china for sale, a bit like a car boot sale, but more up market. Lovely old building with carved arches.

Very nice building and inside a very artistique vibe. You can buy old stuff (glases, vases, paintings, coins) from around the 50s and on but also can find some new items as comic books and so. A nice suprise and greatly enjoyed it!
Very european, Excelent start point to Vieux-lille. I Ioved the young band playing live music in the square.
Stunning building with a bizarre arty thing in the middle of loads of inflated fruits, great browsers market of books, maps, music and antiquea

This impressive building was built in the 1600's to offer an indoor space for merchants who previously sold their goods in the outdoor " wheat market." They petitioned for this building to be built after several seasons of poor weather and sickness of merchants. There were
If you are in the heart of Old Town in Lille, you cannot miss it. It's one of the nicest building around the square.

If you enjoy looking at great architecture head for the Grand Place in Lille. One of the buildings there is the Old Stock Exchange. There were to let signs in the windows of the building but if you go through a door way it will bring you out in a small courtyard where there is

Built in 1653, this is definitely the most beautiful building in the city. It is made up of 24 identical houses surrounding a cloister. Inside the cloister there is a booksellers and antiques market held in the afternoons where you can walk around free of charge and browse the
What a great building! Great example of a guilded building! Perfect place to visit after work...easy to access, plenty of information and lots of very interesting information.
If you like prints, old books and magazines, allow plenty of time for browsing, as there are thousands of them to look at and to suit all budgets.

Easy to get to, right on the Grand Place - you can get there by bus, metro and easiest of all, walking. There are stalls selling books and 'antiques' most days. There isn't an awful lot to do in Lille so, on that basis, it's worth a visit.
Wonderful old building that on the afternoon, the interior courtyard is open and has antique and vintage books, bric a brac and the odd postcard or two for sale.

Very nice square old building with a central courtyard with columns, waheresecond hand books and comics are for sale. Formerly was in this building the corporations for their trade. Business was not bad according to the richness of the building! No fee, you may walk through the

Wander in to enjoy the architectural features and admire the inside of the building. Explore the stalls and the antiques or just go in to hide from the heat or rain for a while. You may also want to visit on Sunday night when a French version of passion tango is danced by dozens
Well preserved building worth visiting if your in the area. It's very central so all the shops, cafes, restaurants etc are all in the area. Nice square and few good cafes to sit and people watch.

This old stock exchange is in the heart of the city. It is well renovated and a beautifull sight. You can walk into the build In its interior there is a a market for old comic books music albums, historic post cards. Ideal to look for treasures.

If you visit Sunday nights you can watch the Lille tango club - a wonderful experience! We did not go into the building but on other days the trading square becomes a flea market. It is a pretty building on the side of the Grand Place - very easy to find
a grand place for shopping and very enjoyable to visit , would love to come again and do more shopping
A wonderful building, great from all sides and perfectly located on the main square of Lille. Did not go in, though.
One of the most beautiful buildings in the center of Lille is well worth walking around and admiring the details. Go inside for a small flee market.
With a second-hand book market on the Saturday and locals ball-room dancing to a band there on Sunday evening, place this was a bit of a surprise! Nice piece of architecture too.
This building on the Square is one of many wonderful architectural joys all over the city. Don't just look out side, go in to the court yard and check out the amazing interior with its book sellers.

Built on the edge of the main sqaire, the old exchange is a powerful post-remaissance building in a typical flemish style. Do not forget to take a peek in the beautiful courtyard with it's stone colums.
One of many interesting buildings in Lille centre; definately worth a visit. Check out the cafes in the squaures

This lovely old stock exchange is worth at least a quarter of an hour of anyone's time ... Pause and look at the grand exterior, then enjoy a wander round the interior courtyard (it is free to enter) with its swags and sculptured details, or watch a game of chess or browse

There are many attractive buildings in Lille, sadly though we didn't like the atmosphere of the place. It is run down and there are a lot of homeless people on the streets (lots of children on the streets too). When we tried to park up there were dodgy guys in some of the car
Make the effort to visit this place in the middle of town. Very interesting history and an array of antique and antique book stalls. Splendid even in the rain.
I am one who loves great architecture so seeing fantastic buildings like this makes me happy. I love old places.
Towering structure. Dominates skyline. Tower has wonderful sculpted features. You can envision the financial deals that were struck in this very building. Gives the impression of wealth.
Massive number of secondhand bookstalls around central courtyard. many unusual items, including books on local history, art and science.
Definitely one of the highlights of the Old City. Very well preserved on the inside and outside. Be sure to go into the inner courtyard and look up at all the carvings.

This is really a historical building located just in the Grand Place, so it was one of the main building for activity of people in the past. The interior with famous people in France name on the wall, can be something interesting. Beside the building itself, the antique-second

We walked through it rather than visited it as there isn't anything to see really and nothing of interest was being sold on the market stalls. You may as well see it while you are in Lille centre but I wouldn't get excited about it.

La Grand Place in Lille is such a beautiful and impressive square, and the absolute highlight is the Vielle Bourse - the Old Stock Exchange, built in 1653. The style is Flemish renaissance, and the whole building is decorated within an inch of its life with swags and garlands,
wonderful house, very nice flee-market-style book-stands in the court with graphic art, comics, vinyl-LPs and such

I've discovered this place while visiting the city with my Swedish friend, I'm from Lille but I had never got into the old stock Exchange before (what I shame I know). It is so pretty and amateurs of old books, posters, etc. will love to walk around and find the special
Uniquely beautiful and historic building with a "flea market" inside. Not open every day, and not every stand open on open days. Many old books, prints and collectibles.

The building is interesting, but you should stop by for the flea market even if just to see. They usually have some books and old magazines and such on sale. It's not much, but it'll be on your path to any destination in Lille or a very short detour, so why not check it out.
This is a fascinating piece of architecture - and trading still goes on today, with a flea market under the covered areas.

A very interesting building to photograph and wander through - and it is free - some market stalls inside that were of specialist interest old books posters newspapers etc. Look for the English translation of its history in one of the 4 entrances
you can buy some old posters or books inside, nice to walk through the building, but we stayed not more then 15 minutes
Unfortunately it was closed when we were there but the views of the outside are breathtaking. Do the ferris wheel and you will get great views of the entire city center.
Seeing such a building in the middle of the city is always a pleasant experience.It is very similar tot the building style of Flanders
Nice building, great architecture, witness of the great history of the city of Lille, ... A must see when you are in Lille.
This is a very nice location to visit. It immediately takes you back to the past. Nicely restored. When we visited there was a bookmarket going on.
In winter or in summer, this building is always so beautiful. Inside you will find a small market, selling anything from old books to old currencies or old coins...worth walking though..
I was hoping to see the cloister type internal square. However everything was closed. It looked fairly interesting from the outside in a prominent position in the middle of "The Grand Place".
Good information on local history with panels showing well know people with connections to Lille. Second-hand books, CD, bande dessinée sold here at the weekend.
One of the best buildings in Lille with a book market in the inner courtyard. Right in the centre so very easy to find. Nothing to dislike.

The Old Stock Exchange shown on the City Tour, but It is worthwhile to walk around the villa entrance with posters, old interesting books, long playing records. The building is very decorative with gold.
Interesting books from crime paperbacks, old copies of Vogue to rare editions along with some glass wear and stuffed birds. Also original copies of posters and prints. Copies at reasonable prices.
great place to buy some old book or stamp collection. Open every weekend, the place is wonderful chance for you to find some "vintage" stuffs.
It's a pretty building with some nice book stores in it, but can't see spending more than 30 minutes here
Every first Sunday in the evening music and tango dancing, at other times antiquarians book market. Recommended
The building is amazing but that is all. There are many antique sellers and if you like that type of thing then I'm sure you would enjoy it. It is well worth a look but that is really about it!
Interesting building but not much too it. Books and other bric-a-brac for sale, OK if in a car but not much good on the train.
Secondhand bookstalls are a delight if you like rummaging, the architecture is beautiful and I at is just fun to wander around

Beautiful building just off La Grande Place. In the inner courtyard there are stalls with lots of old books, postcards, prints, posters, bric a brac for sale and a wonderful place to spend some time. None of the sellers hassled you (in fact it was hard to see who or where they
I just love this place i love the atmosphere , The building is beautiful .... If You go to Lille just go There

A beautiful courtyard building with lots of interesting features both inside and out. There are lots of stalls on the inside selling bric-a-brac, collectibles, books, coins, paintings etc. Certainly worth a visit for a few minutes or longer if you have the time

one of the symbols of the city. in the main centre. in this area u can see the most beautiful buildings of the city
Very nice architecture in most of Lille but the Stock Exchange is one of the highlights. And if you search for long enough you can get some posters from the stalls inside

It's history, it's architecture, it's book market. It was beautifully lit up during the Christmas market

You need one day to visit the important points of interest and there is no real need to spend a night here. I strongly suggest a walking tour.

Really nice square

Beautiful architecture, if you love old books that's the place.
Impressive architecture

Beautiful old building. You see the style of the past. When the sun is shining on the building it looks so great.

Love this city 💛
A treasure trove of old skool vinyl, books, paintings and memorabilia. A must visit if you're in Lille Centre Grande Place before heading to Vieux Lille.

Had an enjoyable day here. Just a bit to busy wanted to go and see market lit up but to busy

Loved it. It was my first visit to Lille and this is definitely a must see. The area around is also great for a walk.

The city center of Lille. When you go to this place during the Christmas market you get to see lots of fun stuff. When you visit Lille you can’t miss this place. Don’t forget to buy a souvenir :) One more thing, don’t forget to try the local food :D

The Vieille bourse in Lille is a beautiful historic building.

text.wiki:
Bamse – Världens starkaste björn (Swedish for 'Bamse – The World's Strongest Bear') is a Swedish cartoon created by Rune Andréasson. The highly popular children's cartoon first emerged as a series of television short films as well as a weekly half-page Sunday strip in 1966, before being published periodically in its own comic magazine since 1973.
Andréasson did all the artwork himself until 1975 and wrote all the comics until 1990. Francisco Tora did all the illustrations from 1976 until he was joined by Bo Michanek in 1983. Several new writers and illustrators were hired in the early 1990s, including Claes Reimerthi, Anna Friberger and Tony Cronstam. Andréasson continued to do the magazine cover illustrations until 1992.
The series somewhat changed direction when Bamse had children, specifically triplets, in 1982. He had a fourth child in 1986, and his friend Lille Skutt had one at the same time; this saw the series focus more on family, while also discussing other values such as gender equality. In 1989, the character Skalman noticed that Bamse's fourth child Brumma had some intellectual disability, later defined as Asperger's syndrome, which again brought up the subject of equality. The children did develop in real time within the magazine, but seem to have been fixed in age since around 1990. They are now around nine years old, in a narratively advantageous eternal state as third-graders.
Both the early Sunday strips and the early magazines have since been reprinted as glossy hardbound volumes.
In 1998, the theme park 'Bamses Värld' ("Bamse's World") started as an attraction at the Kolmården Zoo, with theater performances, restaurant and houses from the comic.


== Characters ==


=== Protagonists ===
Bamse, the main character, is a brown bear who becomes the world's strongest bear by eating a type of honey called dunderhonung (lit. "thunder-honey"), specially prepared for him by his grandmother. (Almost) anyone else who eats it, apart from Bamse's pet bee and his daughter Brumma, ends up with three days of stomach ache. Bamse is also the kindest bear in the world (according to the comic), and is often seen helping those in need. The name Bamse comes from a Scandinavian word for "bear" or "teddy bear". "Bamse" can also translate to "giant" or "big one", though that would be something of a misnomer, as Bamse is rather diminutive in size compared to many of the other characters.
Brummelisa ("Growlelisa") is the daughter of a forester who could always rely on Bamse helping out; soon they fell in love. In 1981, they all went on a boat trip to the north of Scandinavia (financed by individual odd jobs), climaxing in a view of the midnight sun (an anti-climax to grandma's cat and mouse who expected it to look different). Back home, Brummelisa and Bamse staged a secret wedding and became parents to triplets: Brum ("Growl"), Teddy, Nalle-Maja ("Teddy-Maja"). Brum is artistically gifted, but somewhat shy. Teddy spends a lot of time by himself, and loves reading and learning. Nalle-Maja is the most extrovert kid, and loves sports and activities. Once their personalities began to shine through Teddy gravitated towards Skalman who noticed what the others failed to; Teddy's clumsiness stems from his eyesight and only needed a pair of glasses. Nalle-Maja has inherited more than just her father's looks; she also inherited his ability to get strong from the dunderhonung. To prevent her from injuring herself or her brothers, Bamse's grandmother attempted a new dunderhonung recipe to avoid making her strong. She partially succeeded; Nalle-Maja draws strength from it, but also winds up with the stomach ache. Late 1985 the triplets were informed on the arrival of another sibling; Brumma ("Growla"), who - when eating Dunderhonung - neither gets strong nor is affected by the stomach ache.
Lille Skutt ("Little Hop") is Bamse's and Skalman's best friend. He is a very fast but notoriously frightened white rabbit with a red bow tie. However, his ability to run quick and jump far (not to mention braving his fears whenever someone he cares about is in danger) has saved his friends' skins on more than one occasion. Lille Skutt is the village postman, albeit on a part-time basis. He also works part-time as the head chef of the local restaurant. Like Bamse, Skutt ended up marrying his girlfriend; Nina Kanin ("Nina Rabbit"), best friend with Brummelisa. Nina and Skutt became parents to a son Mini-Hopp ("Mini-Hop"), a hyperactive kid with an apparent lack of fear. He has eight siblings including Happ. Happ is a gay rabbit. He and his life-partner Lille Sixten have adopted a little girl named Suddan who is around Mini-Hopp's age.
Skalman ("Shellman" / "Shellback") is an ingenious tortoise who invents all sorts of things, including spacecraft and time machines. He stores just about anything in his carapace except for locomotives, spaceships or atlantic steamboats (and also firewood, due to him getting splinters in the back). Skalman seems to be a polyphasic sleeper, and according to himself, his best invention is the food-and-sleep clock, whose calls he follows slavishly, even at times when sleep seems highly inappropriate. To this date, he has only ignored the alarm call a few times, including the discovery of a dinosaur's egg, the birth of Bamse's children, and a state of deep depression due to the false belief that his carelessness had caused the death of Bamse's children. None of the other characters come close to Skalman's intellectual level and he is sometimes seen playing chess with himself (he has stated that he has met and beaten the chess world champion). Rune Andréasson has stated that he brought the food-and-sleep clock into the series for much the same reason as the dunderhonung; during a dangerous adventure, Skalman could just pull something out of his carapace to save them, or help the trio with his intellect. That's when the food-and-sleep clock calls Skalman to sleep, forcing Bamse and Lille Skutt to think on their own.
Vargen ("The Wolf") is a black wolf who was the original main villain (later anti-hero) of the comic; a criminal and a bully who at one point was named "World Champion of Evil" by his colleagues, but who later on proved to not be such a bad person if given a chance. Vargen grew up on the wrong side of the tracks and was introduced to a life of crime by his villainous stepfathers. When they eventually ended up in prison he knew that it was time to make a fresh start but his past turned against him as nobody wanted to give him the chance to better his life. Bamse, however, did, and eventually managed to reform the wolf by consistently treating him with kindness. Vargen occasionally slips back into his old ways, but as far as the other wolves are concerned he blew it by joining Bamse's club.


=== Antagonists ===
Krösus Sork ("Croesus Vole") is an often cruel capitalist and secondary villain of the comic; born as a banker's son he was forced to play second fiddle to his brother Slösus (rough translation "Wasteus") who couldn't put a foot wrong. After Slösus later won a lottery (ticket no 88), Krösus forged his own ticket (no 89), switched the tickets, claimed Slösus' prize and let the unknowing Slösus get detained for forgery while coming to pick up his prize. Slösus was devastated to discover the truth after his release and they had a falling-out. Meanwhile, Krösus built up his fortune with blood money and let other voles do the dirty jobs. While Krösus has on occasion showed some small shred of conscience, he is still by far the most amoral and ruthless of the comic's villains; willing to do just about anything for profit.
Kapten Buster ("Captain Buster") and his three clumsy sideman pirates, Rusken, Slusken and Stollen. (Approximate translation: "Rover,  Sloven and Silly".) They are largely incompetent and unsuccessful, and have mostly given up their life at sea thanks to a tendency towards seasickness.
Knocke & Smocke, ("Knocker & Socker") two large thugs with flat caps who have performed several unsuccessful criminal attempts. They usually rely mainly on brute force and are generally outwitted by Skalman or others.
Reinard is a sly fox and the newest main villain of the comic; who became an addition to the crew in 2006. He is shown to engage in all kinds of villainy, from shoplifting to explicit attempts on Bamse's life (which, curiously, has resulted in no retribution, or even rebuking, from Bamse's side).


== Moral values and criticism ==
The magazine has educational goals. On special "school" pages, the characters educate the reader about animals, cultures, the Universe, and other subjects. They often deal with superstition, and Skalman's sceptical views ("I only believe in what I know") wins over those of his more naive friends. On the other hand, beings like trolls, tomtar and dragons exist on a very real plane in most of the stories. As the series have evolved, the values expressed have become more general and less ideological. A fact sheet written and published by Andreasson in 1983 following a trip to the People's Republic of China became very controversial as it seemed to praise Mao Zedong's dictatorial rule as a "liberation" and claimed that "nobody's starving anymore" in China under Communist single-party rule. It was later edited heavily when the adventure was reprinted in 2004.
Bamse and his friends are very clear about their views. They are strongly opposed to racism, bullying and violence. Bamse is not only the strongest bear in the world, but also the kindest, often repeating his slogan "Nobody gets better from being beaten". Bamse's own world seems to have strong implications of anarchism or libertarian socialism, combining private ownership with communitarian solidarity (from most of the characters), though a single policeman, Pontus Kask (named for his classic-style policeman's helmet, or "kask" in Swedish) and a small prison exists.
The original villain, a black wolf simply called Vargen ("The Wolf"), became a friend of Bamse after consistently being treated kindly. The only villain that is depicted as unredeemable is Krösus Sork ("Croesus Vole"), a crude capitalist who will do practically anything for money.


== Films and other media ==
Six animated black-and-white short films were produced for television in 1966. In 1972, seven more animated shorts were shown in colour. Another two shorts were released in 1981, and a direct-to-video movie became available in 1991.
The later colour films have aired frequently on TV in Sweden, and have been released on VHS and DVD. The black and white films had been unavailable to the general public for a long time, but were released on DVD by late 2006. The colour movies were low-budget productions with actor Olof Thunberg narrating and voicing all characters, but are considered to be classics. The musical theme, composed by Sten Carlberg, is easily recognised by most Swedes.
In 1993, a Game Boy game (in Swedish) was published loosely based on the Bamse characters. The game received generally poor reviews; it was in fact little more than a sprite replacement of Beam Software's Baby T-Rex, which explains the game's setting. The "Bamse version" is not the only time this happened; the game went through the same procedure for other regions featuring other characters. The "Bamse version" has not been officially released outside Sweden.
In October 2006, forty years after Bamse was created, Ola Andréasson, the son of creator Rune Andréasson announced that an animated feature film would be made, featuring better animation, a full voice cast, and a budget of SEK 25 million. An estimated release date of 2012 for the film was proposed. It was finally released in 2014 as Bamse and the Thief City. The film was followed by Bamse and the Witch's Daughter in 2016.


== Translations ==
In the 1960s, there were a few translations of the series "Bamses skola" ("Bamse's school"), where the characters were given English names:
Bamse - Bamsy
Skalman - Professor Shellback
Lille Skutt - Little Frisky
Vargen - Willie
Farmor - Granny
Katten Janson (literally Janson the Cat) - SootyIn this translation, the dunderhonung was given the name magic honey. However, in the 1980s, Andréasson referred to it in English as thunder-honey, which is the literal translation also used in the Netherlands and Belgium (donderhoning).
In the cancelled movie Bamse and the Time-Travel Machine from 2009, the names were translated differently:

Bamse - Bamse
Skalman - Shellman
Lille Skutt - Little Skip
Krösus Sork - Victor Vole
Dunderhonung - Superhoney


== References ==


== External links ==
Bamse - Official site (in Swedish)
Official site for Bamses värld (in Swedish)

Great place to visit with kids and family. Good price, facilities and service. Wide range of animals
