text.quote: Large museum with a respected collection of European art from ancient times to the modern period.
trip: Ignorant uncultured savage that I am, I sometimes get bored in galleries, but not here. It's ridiculously cheap for the quality of art on show and nothing like as crowded as galleries often are.

This museum, already a grand building in itself, is a real wonderful museum. Especially its collection of paintings is superb, with dutch/flemish greats like Rubens, Breughel and van Dyck and also other great artists like the Picasso and the french impressionists. It is special

This was really a fantastic place to visit. It is an art museum with wonderful collections. Gallery 17 was amazing - you could get so close to Van Gogh, Toulouse Lautrec, Monet, Rodin etc. On 3 floors there is something wonderful to see at each turn. Also 2 for 1 ticket if you
I went primarily to see the historical maps on the basement. They did not disappoint! Well laid out and labelled they were a fascinating record of the history of northern French and Belgian towns.

The paintings highlighted on the Palais website - Bosch, Breugel, Degas, Rodin, Matisse etc. - really are the highlights and unless you're really into 19th century neoclassicism and stock religious themes you may find many of the painting galleries and sculptures pretty heavy
Best way to enjoy Sunday rainy afternoon, specially when it is first Sunday of the month and the entrance to the museum is free.
The museum has a big collection of all ages/periods. It’s not very busy so lots of space to wander around.
The Palais des Beaux Arts is a must visit when in Lille. Beautiful works of art spanning from the 15th century to modern art.

We were on a day trip to the Christmas markets, on arriving in Lille the heavens opened and we needed to escape from the downpours. We headed one stop past the centre on the metro and arrived at the gallery, which has a metro station directly outside. As we travelled to Lille on

Wonderful setting for wonderful art. The collection was a bit smaller than we'd imagined, especially in such a spacious setting and while the ground floor collection is beautifully displayed some of the upper rooms feel under-lit - but overall a stunning art gallery. The map

The collection isn't huge but it's varied and really good. The relief maps of the old towns in the lower ground, the sculptures around the atrium and the paintings on the first floor provided a couple of interesting and enjoyable hours. The helpful guy on the ticket desk said

Really, if you love art, don’t visit here. A beautiful building with paintings in an interior so gloomy that it’s really difficult to see anything. In addition, some of them have darkened with age and could be cleaned, so the overall effect is extremely frustrating.

Quite a find it was to visit such a gorgeous art museum in a relatively small city such as Lille. Amazing collection, from trully extraordinary modells of the old fortified cities of the region, through some great paintings, to the fabulous sculptures, among which, one of

I read that this museum was second only to the Louvre. Who can resist that. But there is something amiss with the curator or the management of this museum. They haven't lit the paintings. Yes, I know, impossible to believe. And it was. The only lighting for most of the art is a

We spent over an hour here yesterday and although we had been before there were new exhibits and a well constructed section on artists and how they began. We were given a map but actually it was easy to find one’s way round because every room was well signposted. There is a cafe

Spent a couple of hours here wandering around the exhibits. Stunning place with loads to see. Particularly loved the impressionist section. There are a lot of paintings and sculptures so plenty to see, plus a temporary exhibition worthy of a visit until 6 January 2020. A jewel

It has the usual permanent collection of a municipal art gallery plus a temporary exhibition space, but what makes this one unique is its collection of relief models of the surrounding towns and countryside. Marvel at the level of detail that went into the making of these 300

The Palais de Beaux Arts is huge - but there is plenty of seating so take your time. Worth going up to the first floor where the "serious" stuff is housed. I spent most of my time in the (deserted) medieval galleries in the basement. Fabulous icons and ivories.

This beautiful old building displays some of the art masters works, but not well. The lighting was poor in order to obtain a good clear view of many of the works, especially those high up. We were either stretching over the security devices to get a clearer view or having to

Lots of different types of art, sculptures and artefacts housed in this amazing building. Explore all the floors, 3D maps of French towns and a temporary exhibition whilst we were there. We were lucky to get a 2 for 1 as travelled by Eurostar.

A good collection of paintings covering the 12th to 20th centuries (although the latter was thinly represented). Many of the paintings seemed to be associated with artists that reflected Lille's position on the borders of France and historically the Spanish, then Austrian,
Second only to Louvre Museum. Great paintings by famous artist. Extremely interesting 3D maps of French towns, originally made for king Louis 14th.
I was surprised at how much art and artifacts you can see in this museum. We spent a couple of hours there and could have easily spent more time.

A beautiful gallery in a stunning building, an easy walk from the town centre. You MUST make it a compulsory part of your Lille visit to see the stunning relief plans from the 17th & 18th centuries in the basement, absolutely beautiful. Watch out for opening times, like much

We went to the museum on a Sunday and got free admission. Large bags to be left in the cloakroom free of charge. Museum on 3 levels. Ground floor very under-utilised. Cafe very expensive, avoid. Ground floor hosts sculptures & pottery inc Delph and Limoges. Upper floor hosts
Vast collection classical art, sculpture and limited impressionists - the ceramics were particularly good. Very hard to navigate - both entering and within the museum.

The gallery is situated in Place De La République and is close to the République-Beaux Arts metro station on line 1. It houses primarily classical art although there is a corridor with a small selection of Impressionist art. Donatello, Veronese, Raphael, Goya, El Greco and

Really impressive large building, however I didn't think they had made the most of all the space they have, particularly on the ground floor, which is mainly empty. The first floor has a reasonable number of paintings on display, although quite a few had been removed and

The building is gorgeous and there is a lot to see. Not only sculpture (check out the statue of Napoleon that used to stand in the courtyard of the old stock exchange), but also China, jewels, clocks, watches, religious art, Egyptian artefacts and paintings galore! You can
Gorgeous building with a splendid collection within! Thoroughly enjoyed my time wandering around viewing the art within it's walls.

Firstly, if you travel by Eurostar, show your ticket for a 2 for 1 entry. There was an interesting mix of artefacts, paintings, sculptures and religious objects. Museum currently undergoing works in some parts and disappointingly they have discontinued the audio guides which

A lovely classical building and worth walking round it to the more modern building behind it. The Palais houses the art exhibition but we decided the price was a bit steep and the art rather too old for our tastes - maybe we'd just had enough walking around by then!

Compared to other French regional museums there is a partial emphasis on large religious paintings taken from Belgian churches. The most interesting paintings are masterpieces from lesser known artists and secondary but beautiful paintings from Rubens, Goya, Velasquez, Bosch,

Be sure to visit the "maps", 3-D terrain maps, in the lower level created for Louis XIV of nearby cities where he anticipated engaging in battle. The art collection is very nice but the pink wall for the impression needs to be rethought.

This is a very interesting museum lots of famous artists fabulous building but really nothing in English I know I am in France but if you like tourists then It would be nice tf we could know more about the art then the artist name very disappointed one of the reasons I go to

A bit off the tourist path is the very not crowded Palais. The art collection includes pieces by Bruegel, Picasso, Manet, Monet, among others. A cool feature includes an interactive display where you can zoom in to see the very fine details of certain paintings.

Good reduction here with Eurostar tickets, 2 for 1. Staff very nice and helpful apart from the cafe where staff were eating and couldn’t be bothered with customers so as I write this I’d like to make them aware of what customer service is, they had a different attitude to a
If you have a spare moment you could spend a visit here. Not very big nor exciting museum. We went in to avoid the rain outside.

The building was impressive inside and out. The works of art were interesting and varied. Arranged on three levels with plenty of space to view each piece. Especially The Atrium as you enter the building. We used our Eurostar tickets to get 2 for 1 on the entrance fee of 7 Euros.
Amongst France's best galleries outside the 2 in Paris. Works from all styles and nations, well displayed in a cool, wellorganised classical building. Helpful staff
Great museum filled up with lovely paintings. Good space and a lttle nice cafe for a break. Go and visit!

the Palais des Beaux-Arts i Lille is the second most important art museum in France after the Louvre in Paris. its easily reached by high speed train from Paris or car. its is beautifully done , and laid out ,spacious with and incredible collection from all well known artists

Not being a connoisseur of museums or architecture, I think that this museum is one of the most impressive ones I have visited. We started our tour at level -1 where mainly religious statues and medieval wooden reliefs were on display. The combination of beautifully restored

The layout of this gallery is fantastic, stunning in size and quality, we paid €7 to get in, and got to see something priceless. I am never too sure about modern art, most times I stare bewildered, but it’s well laid out and well informed. Upstairs is a gift for art lovers and

Visited as part of a day trip to Lille from the UK by Eurostar. After walking from the station in the morning to the Belfry, we walked to the nearby Palais des Beaux-Arts de Lille. The entry price was halved by us showing out Eurostar tickets which was a bonus, as the entry

We heard that the Palais de Beaux Arts in Lille had newly exhibited their large collection of Asian and European porcelain, also lots of beautifil European earthenware, so went for a visit. We were pleasantly surprised by this large collection, also their 17th and 1th century

I spent about two hours here and didn't see everything, notably the sculptures. It has a large collection of European paintings, particularly strong on the Low Countries in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. The presentation is rather crowded. A computer-assisted

As grand as the building appears from the outside, one can expect the same level of grandness for its collection as well. Divided into proper sections, one can explore their exhibitions as per their liking. I visited the museum on a Wednesday and I got free access to the

Unfortunately time only permitted us to see this beautiful building from the outside, but we loved its architecture, sheer size and the huge open spaces to the front, from where it can really be appreciated to the best.

We came here as a family (of grown-ups!) for an afternoon. The entry fee of €7.00 was really reasonable as there were many beautiful works of art to see. I particularly enjoyed the 19th and 20th Century exhibits. Would definitely come back - the whole building is beautiful.

The museum is much smaller inside than it looks from outside. However is leaves with very pleasant feeling and has well-appointed collection of fine arts incl. very famous names. Absolute must if you are visiting Lille.
On the west side of the city centre you can locate this marvellous building, currently have some upgrade and tidy up and so the fountains aren't on, but well worth your time to visit.

Lille claims to be the second city of France and the Musee de Beaux-Arts de Lille is really splendid. If you have travelled to Lille by Eurostar you get two entries for the price of one. We did not have enough time as you could easily spend a day looking around and still have
Nice art but not all of the exhibits were open. Nothing special but the outside of it is very pretty in a nice area of lille! Try and go on a Sunday since it should be free on one Sunday a month.

I did have a great time visiting this Palais and exploring many paintings and sculptures in this institution. It was truly a cultural feast to see Monet’s The London Parliament, Merson’s Le Loup d’Agubbio or Goya’s Time and the Old Women. There is an audio guide available but

Visited this museum while on a weekend in Lille, and really enjoyed our visit. The building is very imposing and there is plenty of art to see! The paintings are well displayed, and unlike other Beaux Art that I have visited did not have a propensity towards religious paintings.

My husband and I were somewhat disappointed with our visit to the Palais des Beaux-Arts de Lille. We did not find the staff very welcoming or helpful to English speakers. The young man at the ticket desk volunteered no information and seemed uninterested in speaking with us.
What an amazingly well curated gallery. Easy to follow plan and a true celebration of many masterpieces.

The building is beautiful and worth a quick visit. There are a lot of paintings some more well known than others. If you enjoy this kind of visit and if the weather is cold outside then it is worth a wander. We were surprised to find out that on a Saturday you do not pay.
We had a Lille Card so on a rainy afternoon, spent a couple of hours wandering around the museum. To be honest, we prefer history rather than art, but the building was very interesting.

We visit this 'attraction' on Thursday 07 March 2019 and left very disappointed. Here are the reasons why: It is poorly signed from neighbouring streets and you only know you are there when close-by. The painting collection is very uniform: far too much religious-themed only

This was on my list to visit and I was not disappointed. The building is imposing and well maintained. The paintings are varied and yes there are a lot of religious scenes but they were standard for the time. There were sculptures by Rodin, paintings by Constable, Napoleon,

Was one of my targets for my Lille visit and was not disappointed. A mixture of paintings and sculptures of which, the paintings are the star of the show. I don't recall seeing a Rembrandt but just about ever other major artist over the last 500 years peeks out. Very
The gallery is the second largest in France after the Louvre. It has some very famous paintings and a collection of pottery. There is a smallish cafe.

Lovely building, great staff who kindly told us about the 2 for 1 ticket option if you have your Eurostar tickets with you. Everything is in French even the new interactive gigapixel experience where you can zoom into the detail of a few selected paintings. It took me ages to
Excellent value and just half price entry if you show your Eurostar ticket. Amazing art and ancient artefacts

Great building all well presented, spacious and light and airy. A few nice exhibits, with just enough to interest. No pretender at greatness, but we enjoyed a peaceful few hours. One famous Monet, and a small Rodin.

This is a real gem of a museum located in Lille. The collection is fantastic and very reasonably priced to enter. Highly recommended, especially if you are after a huge variety of art under one roof. When we travelled (Feb 2019) you could get 2 for 1 entry with a Eurostar ticket.

We went there several times, and saw some very good temporary exhibitions, like the one about Millet. Outside of special exhibitions, I have been a bit disappointed by the permanent collection that I found a bit too common for such a big city as Lille.

The Palais des Beaux Artes is a wonderful building. Make sure to watch the history presentation in the relaxing area on the main floor. While the building is magnificent, the exhibit itself is scattered, lacking direction. The antiquities section was closed when we visited. The
A huge building housing lots of art. Paintings and sculptures as well as temporary exhibitions. The lighting isn’t always good but plenty of different styles and art periods.

I liked this museum, but agree with some of the other reviewers that the lighting in the museum is a serious problem. Too dark or too bright. Also the collection does not seem very logically arranged and it is hard to navigate the place. Explanations/discussions of art work

Give it a minimum of half a day and take time, as we did to explore the collection. El Grecos, Goyas, Monets Vuillards are all to be enjoyed. The basement has some good medieval artefacts and paingings and there is an amazing Donatello bas - relief which should not be missed.

After reading other reviews we thought this worth a visit, as it said it was only second to the Louvre. It cost €14 for two of us, but I would have to say it wasn't worth the money. Some areas are so dark you can hardly see the items on display, and the art is not varied

Rather disappointing. We got in on a 2for1 deal using our Eurostar ticket but there is very little to guide you around once you are in. Endless rooms of paintings with poor lighting, no presentation and no explanation of the exhibits other than title artist etc in French. No

Wonderful building, not too busy when we were there, helpful staff, average collection of art compared to galleries in major cities, and a nice way to get out of the Lille sun/rain. TOP TIP: KEEP YOUR EUROSTAR TICKET - IT GIVES YOU A 2 FOR 1 DEAL so the gallery is pretty good
Seems to be half price admission, or two for one, for Eurostar travellers. Great art gallery with some fabulous paintings by Picasso, Klimt, Breughel, Bosch and many more.

The audio commentary was one an ipod and no headphones available so you could hear people listening to this, which was very offputting. Also some of the pictures that had symbols against them, ie should have commentary, did not. I'd have liked more translations of the

The art available for viewing was ok. Then I made the mistake of ordering a slice of pizza for lunch. Twenty-five minutes later I was finally served my meal. It was not worth the wait. I didn’t expect much but the wait was annoying when the food was so mediocre.

The collection of Palais des Beaux Arts is interesting, although a bit limited when compared to other French cities. The infrastructure of the place seems to be decaying. Toilettes completely out of order. Deficient WiFi. The local café employs the grumpiest people in France.

The Palais has plenty of worthwhile art, enough to fill a rainy afternoon like we had. However, it's the Beau Café which did its best to spoil our visit; given the weather, we planned to eat there, and called in at 12:50pm, only to find a sign which said it was closed until

Visited Lille on a Sunday, museum is one of the few things open on a Sunday. The art collection is really world class. The military plans-reliefs were undergoing restoration until March 2019, really wish I could have seen them as it appears larger than the collection at Hotel

There are an amazing number of paintings, varieties and styles. Some of the great masters, and well known paintings can be seen. A lot are religious, especially Rubens. There is a lot of walking as its a large grand building with stairs. Some pictures were poorly positioned,

I last went to the Lille Palais des beaux arts about 10 years ago. I liked it even more as they now lend freely special ipod with narrative explanations of some art works. Choose the French language option if you can as not all of them are explained in English. The portraits

The 20th century has limited representation , but there are two very good Picassos. There is lot of religious work ( by Rubens and others) and a beautiful still life by Chardin. Current temporary show is of an Egyptian Pharaoh and is well presented but hard going if you are
Second in France only to The Louvre, 22000 square feet of prestigious collections of European paintings from 15th to 20th centuries. Fantastic!

The museum is normally closed on tuesdays. We found it open (30 December) as it was due to be closed on New Year's Day. We were charged the full price (including the exhibition) which was €18 for an adult and under 25. The Egyptian exhibition left a lot to be desired and was

I lived in Lille back in 2012, for about a month, and made a point to know the city; The museum was one of my first stops, and my first let down. In spite of the facts that there are some good pieces in the museum, unless you're going in Sunday morning, it's not worth the
This museum does not receive the credit which it deserves. An exceptional collection of varied interests , with something for all.

This attraction is free on the first Sunday of every month and I would only recommend going then. The building is very impressive from the outside but inside, the collection is quite small and there isn't much variety. The impressionism paintings are enjoyable but the rest of
Must visit when you are in Lille. Nice, varied collection. Same real masterpieces. For us the 'Plans reliefs' were also very interesting.

We got in for free as it turns out that the permanent exhibitions are free for everyone on the first sunday of each month. Bargain! Spent an hour or so wandering the halls (also to get out of the cold). But a good selection of art in there. Worth a look!

We were quite lucky - as it turns out the permanent exhibitions are free on the first sunday of the month, so we got a free visit. Pretty good selection of art in there. They say it is the next biggest after the louvre but I dunno about that. Nice to have a wander though -

One of the main attractions in Lille an imposing and impressive building with an extensive collection ranging from Flemish paintings to Anthony Gormley. The use of an Audio Guide is included in the price of entry although you have to ask for a voucher when you buy a ticket.

One of the best art galleries outside Paris in one of France's less well known cities. Spacious galleries in a beautiful building with all the big names: Renoir, Van Gogh, Manet, Monet, Rubens etc and even a Turner and Constable. Enjoy Brueghel's Le Denombrement de Bethlehem

This is built up as a major attraction but I'm afraid my husband and I found it fairly boring. If you are into Flemish artists, it may be for you. If not, you'll find yourself seeing a good many religious paintings by people you've never heard of.

We took a leisurely tour with audio guide; all the labels are only in French however, and the guide only had partial coverage, and many of the links didn't have any commentary (in English anyway). Lots of Flemish 16-18th C paintings with only few more modern ones; in the

The building itself is gorgeous. Be sure to check out the modern administration building in the back! There is a wonderful collection of art so be sure to give yourself enough time. I suggest doing a bit of research, pick an area and really enjoy it. I'm a fan of Breugle and

A perfect blend of incredible architecture, and great art. I'm a massive Anthony Gormley fan so was excited to see some of his work in the atrium. The rooms are curated well, and host some fascinating pieces. But the building itself is the star. Well worth a visit.

As we were near Lille, we decided to stop and visit the Palais. We were so glad we did - even though parking was interesting in the city centre. (Not for the faint at heart!) If you're lucky, you'll find a spot in the parking garage just in front of the Palais. If not, don't
Nice museum, one of the biggest in lille. Intresting exhibitions, specially for those who like the flamish art.
Great museum, interesting collection, beautiful building, loved the miniatures of the 10 cities in the cellar.

Very impressive building that housed a varied selection of artwork, there were rooms and rooms of very well displayed art including well known paintings. And as an added bonus there was a special exhibition on Ancient Egypt that was really interesting and well set out. The cafe
We passed though the square on a rainy day and it still looked very pretty, Perhaps we will get chance to come back and sit for a while on a sunny day

Worth a wander around although there is an awful lot crammed over 4 floors and many of the 'famous' artists are paintings that are 'attributed to' or 'from the school of' . We enjoyed the Egyptian exhibition but it was fairly limited; interestingly there was a lovely

This is a large popular museum. We went on a Monday afternoon and there were queues all the time until we left. The layout is a bit confusing if you are after a particular section. Spend a few hours just wandering. The scale models of the local towns are amazing and quite eerie

The museum is so beautiful and the location is a must to take a picture place. The square where the museum is also beautiful and a point of meeting the young student people who live in Lille. Around you can find restaurants supermarkets and pharmacies etc.
Really good mixed museum. Free audio unit, free cloakroom and half price entrance with Eurostar ticket.

I visited late in the day, so it was not crowded at all. The staff were very helpful and friendly, some English spoken but obvious willingness to help regardless. My great interest is Impressionism, and their collection was lovely and even included some wonderful artists I'd

This is a very worthwhile provincial museum to visit, with substantial collections of fine arts and other attractions. However some rooms are closed which is annoying and the museum maps are out-of-date.

Entry €7 per person - although show Eurostar tickets and you get 2 for the price of 1. Visited early on a Wednesday afternoon and it was not very busy, giving the chance to appreciate the exhibits at a leisurely pace.
wonderful old building lovely paintings well worth a visit. Staff very helpful and spoke English. Sadly we missed an Egyptian exhibition due to start on 9 October this year.

People say that the museum is the second (after Louvre) in term of number of visitors, but seem to me that it can not compare to Louvre. If you really love arts, wait for the first Sunday each month, then you can enter for free, with also the audio guide.
We used the visual and audio guides and enjoyed our visit very much. Great building and fascinating exhibits.

fascinated by lots of walks. Lille by boat, in the park. The old town with cobbled pavements, art quarter, lots of welcoming restaurants with bistros. Disliked too many beggars everywhere. It spoiled the charm and beauty of this attractive city.

We began our visit in the basement to view the medieval and ancient world collection. The signposts to the basement were unclear, but once we found the stairs, we descended into the dark basement. The first painting we saw was lit from below in such a manner that we could not

We like to visit art galleries and museums but on our first visit here found it was closed. On the second try, after going in (and expecting it to be free as in England) found it to be fairly expensive. No entry prices are displayed outside. We only had 2 hours until our

I have to say that I liked the building more than the exhibits, but I'm not a great fan of renaissance art and religious paintings. Saved for me by the couple of Picasso and Chagall. Go after 6.30 and it is only 4 euros. Worth going for the building if you're not interested in

This was a little harder to find than we expected but was very interesting. A very excitingly designed new extension to the rear was not available to visit, which was disappointing, but the content of the old building was fascinating. They give a portable commentary i-phone/head
A wonderful museum building with great collections. Please visit the city models room with scale models of many regional towns in the reign of Louis XIV.

In truth, I am not a great art gallery person. I tend to get cultural overload after an hour or so and then wander around not really taking anything in. And there is a lot to see at the Palais des Beaux Arts. Obviously it depends on taste but, for me, the entrance fee was

Awonderful museum with some of the world's favourite art in situ. Atmospheric basement exhibits too. Well worth a few hours. Sadly the ground floor was under construction when we visited, but it was still awesome.

This is probably the most well-known tourist attraction in Lille. It is said to be the second or third biggest fine art museum in France. However, the museum is not so big, the collection is not abundant nor wide-range, and the streamline of the flow is a bit weird. Maybe
A very nice and varied collection of paintings, drawings, sculptures and antiquities. Excellent value as well for under 25s (€4). Well worth a visit.

This was a recommended attraction, but a lot of the paintings were 16th and 17th century and were very dark. Not a lot of paintings from 18th and 19th century.Loved the two Goya prints featuring youth and old age.

At 6 euros it is worth a visit. Architecture also amazing. Entrance for wheel chairs is on front part, website gives wrong directions. Lots of paintings, sculptures and artefacts. Some parts depressing and gloomy. Others pleasant. Basement areas spooky and industrial. Not good

The Palais des Beaux Arts is a beautiful museum in a very nice building. It covers good ground on historic paintings during the ages and you can get a good feeling for what paintings different era's represent. I loved the museum and am definitely planning on a second visit later.

This art musee is billed as one of the best in regional France, outside Paris, and that may be true. It is housed in a large ungainly late 19thC building, but the museum was extensively renovated in the 1990s. There is an appealing large vacant internal ground floor space, now
Spent 3 hours here and what a grand election of paintings and artefacts. Second only to the Louvre and you can see why. Go and enjoy (and it is not expensive to enter).

although not as extensive as the Louvre in Paris, the Musee des Beaux Arts in Lille has its own charm. It's housed in a grand palace, and its exhibitions range from ancient Egypt and the Middle ages to Picasso and other modern artistes. 4 euros with the audioguide if youre a

Second visit to the best gallery out side of Paris I understand. You can hire hand held devices which explain every thing in English but you need your passport to hire one. A park like area in front of the gallery looks great on a sunny day although not as great as on the rain
A very pleasant museum. Was there on a Sunday afternoon and it was very quiet, which is an added bonus nowadays. Very interesting collection with some top works of art. Recommended.
The museum has a varied collection that is worth seeing and the facade of the museum is gorgeous. Note that on the first Sun on each month museums are free.
Not very inspiring and exciting. Few famous pieces, little information. Nice to visit when in Lille, 2 hours max is all you need, including coffee.

This is apparently France's second best Musee des Beaux Arts and we certainly enjoyed our visit. Fantastic sculptures (with good english explanations of the important works on the free audio guide) , great historical pieces, a wonderful collection of paints old and new and then

The art gallery is set in a most impressive building dating from the late 1800's, with large grand halls and stairways. There is an audio commentary and a suggested list of artwork to see which helped up get to see the best works of art. For me the best thing was a Monet of the
Interesting museum. Good layout. Staff very unfriendly. Children's interactive console very good but only in French. .

We had to stay over night in Lille due to travel arrangements and were very happy to find the Palais de Beaux Arts. What a gem! The museum is close to the city center, had fantastic art and overall was a great surprise! It's a definate must see when travelling in Lille!
Well worth a visit, so much to see, good value and very good drinks at reasonable price in the cafe.

This is a simply stunning collection of work fro across Europe both secular and sacred. Beautifully arranged and exhibited on three panoramic floors. Highlights were the 20th Century Paintings, Picasso gets everywhere, the relief maps in the basement gallery and for our visit

That's it really the lighting was poor which is a great shame and frustrating for the visitor. One painting was so dark it was impossible to make out the subject matter at all. Personally the overall feel of being surrounded by dark religious oils was quite depressing The

This was a good break from the rain in Lille. The collections are good and arranged in an easy to follow way. The stand out is the Egyptian artefacts on -1. The mummified cat is awesome! The only problem is the audio guide (english) didn't match many of the numbers throughout

As this is styled as the next best museum in France to the Louvre we had high expectation but were dissapointed. the vast building is not utilised to its full extent. It is mainly art works, plus a few antiquities and china.The scale models of towns andthe background to their

I found the painting collections ok. I've probably been spoiled by Louvre, Rijksmuseum, etc. I liked the Medieval sculpture collection: some exquisite works in there. Some halls are made more interesting by the use of music composed by the band Air, which add a sound tapestry to
Good collection of artworks, including, understandably, French masters. The building is impressive and the basement rooms are superb with medieval art.

spent at least two hours in this museum on my last day in lille,if you like art and statues make sure you go here as theres a lot to see and a good little cafe on site,just down the road from the cathedral,everything in lille is within walking distance

We were planning to visit the museum without going in as it was a beautiful day outside. However, there was an interesting expo when we were there so paid the small entrance fee of € 6,50. This includes a video and audio tourguide in English, Dutch or French. Being a novice at
The collections are excellent and the relief town plans of Vauban installations. It would be nice if the museum staff are a bit more helpful - tell you about audio guides etc

Well worth visiting Lille just to go to this galery. Lots of major international art, as well as some more unusual stuff (like giant relief maps of Belgian towns!) in a historic bullding. But without the crowds of the Louvre. You can actually enjoy looking at the pictures.

Second only to the Louvre, but without the queues and the crowds. I.D. only needed if borrowing an audio guide. Excellent art and sculptures. Do not miss out the basement with relief maps of several towns..

Visited in a group of 6 - paid entry fee's as we British do, but noticed other people just walked in and didn't bother paying. Staff not very helpful. We had a small iPod device with earphones attached from another desk - you need identification for these such as a passport or

The entry fee includes an audio guide in English to 50 of the top attractions of the Palais des Beaux-Arts but you need to give a photo ID as surety if you want to use the guide. It's week worth a visit for the Breughels, and the town models in the basement are fascinating if

Fewer 20th century pieces than we expected to see given the size of this building. As one of Lille's major attractions we would have hoped for more sign posts , well at last as many as there are fir Tourist Information Centre. My final winge goes for the fact that you must have

We entered the front doors and after paying the admission fee were confronted by a huge space with Air (the band, currently collaborating with the museum) barely audible! Where was all the artwork? A very strange set up for a museum, with no directions on the walls. Anyway, we
Brimming with old masters and new masters and some stunning items. As good as the Louvre and a lot less crowded

What a wonderful surprise this museum was. The first 2 floors had horrible lighting and not much memorable. But the basement was all German gothic. It was quiet, peaceful and esquisite. I loved it. See blog for more details …

This museum (the second largest in France, I understand) is a must see attraction for the art lover. The building itself is stunning with the exhibitions laid out perfectly. There is currently (April 2014) a sound installation by the band Air (of Moon Safari fame) which adds a

This is an art museum, so if you don't like art, don't come here and magically expect to like it. The museum is located inside and the building outside is picture-worthy. Tickets are 4 euros reduced, 6 adult, I believe. There is a cloakroom (free) where you can store your

Enjoyed the sculptures of Rodin and the galleries. Was surprised to find so many paintings by well known artists. Loved the view of London by Claude Monet. Lovely hot chocolate in the cafe and a very reasonable price for a salad lunch. Well stocked shop with numerous art books,

Nice staff, but the only lift was out of action because of building work in the area. I was with my elderly aunt who is partially sighted and can't do stairs. Had to wait about 15 minutes for someone to come and escort us in lift, and about 10 minutes to go back down. Staff
Interesting collection in lovely surroundings. Nice and quiet when we visited. Only a short stroll from the Grand Place.

Easy to see things in peace, not hard to avoid the schoolchildren (who are well-drilled and interested). A lot of unexpected pleasures, if you aren't expecting all-big-names. You may take (no-flash) photographs. Good information panels near paintings (in French) but

An OK museum to visit if you are killing time, didn't have much time or inclination as the weather was beautiful and it was marred by the number of school children there (although good to see they are visiting!) There's not much to do in Lille to be honest, so this is fine for a
some older exhibitions or somewhat out of date but that adds to the charm; impressionism , naturalism is charming, but renovated cellars with medieval church art and with modern art very impressive
Nothing amazing. Spacious, lovely building to house the art works, but nothing particularly awe inspiring. Not enough info on each piece, and nothing to offer children visiting.

We spent several hours in this museum where there are artefacts from many parts of the world and a fairly impressive art collection. There is a Van Gogh which you could examine really closely (call me a heathen but I now don't know why people think he had so much talent) and

The price for students is only 4 euro's. Not so much for this big museum. We spended there about 3 hours and still hadn't see everything, but went out because we were so hungry (so eat enough before you visit it..). My opinion is that the museum has a great collection due to its

Poor lighting on some exhibits and not very helpful (rude) staff. That is a distinct contrast to the rest of the people we met in Lille. Signage and disabled access very poor. The disbaled ramp was topped of by a chained and padlocked gate. No concessions offered for

A lovely couple of hours spent wandering around the large halls in this art museum. Not everything to our taste but a pretty impressive collection nonetheless. Reasonable entry fee and we particularly found the old city models in the dark basement areas very interesting and

Seems to be after the Louvre one of the finest collections of arts to see : Rubens, Van Dijck, Breughel de jongere, Goya, ... medival and egytian art maquettes (very accurate and on large scale) of fortifications made by vauban (made to show to king Louis XIV) so splendid
I understand the need to protect art form the impact of light damage but parts of the exhibition were so dark you couldn't read what the work was and missed all the detail in the piece.
as one of the largest in France this museum offers a large selection of impressionists and 20th c works early Flemish and some rather typical religious boring stuff in between

I wouldn't say that this museum is second to the Louvre but it is worth a look around if you have a couple of hours to spare. As mentioned by other reviewers the lightening isn't always good enough for the displays and the bright pink hall is very random indeed. Some of the

We saw a wonderful Jan Fabre exhibition with more than 2 dozen large pieces depicting various aspects of life in Congo, all made with scarab beetles (homage to Hieronymus Bosch). But there was also a good collection of 17th and 18th century Dutch and Spanish painters as well

This place has a reasonably good collection, but it is badly hung and poorly lit. Some paintings were impossible to see they were hung so high. The museum seems to rely heavily on natural lighting, but on a dull November day this was not good enough. Bizarrely, one room was very
The painting collection is mediocre, but what bothered the most is the lack of lighting on the paintings. The paintings are very dark (no restorations?) and hardly visible.
A great way to spend a couple of hours. Not too large to get boring. Weird relief maps in the basement room though...not sure what the point of them was.

Went there with my family late afternoon and had a good experience. First the museum itself is an impressive building, worthwhile on its own. Second, the collection is very nice. The staff is very friendly and seem to love their work, including giving one-on-one advise as we

this museum is no way second to the louvre in paris. quite a few of the 'highlignts' were not on display. the lighting on the stair cases (lights on the steps) was a poor choice. good point - the people working there were really friendly.

The splendid building sits in its square with much to invite and much to see. Lighting and labelling left a lot to be desired. In the Middle Ages section which was what I had gone to see, the reflection made it difficult to see many of the pictures except from one angle and then

Grand building but rather down trodden upkeep of the rooms and paintings. Almost impossible to see some of them because of the saloon style hanging and bad lighting. What there was there to see weren't particularly good examples of the artists.
Excellent collection of paintings for every taste including Bosch! beautiful Goya, Rubes, etc. Situated in the heart of the city, close to everything. Definitely worth seeing.
One of the best musea in France. Broad collection of impressionists and 17th Century Dutch and Flamish painters. Indeed not to be missed.

Give this museum at least two hours of your time. Ceramics, oil paintings and sculpture all in a huge space. The building is a short walk from the Grande Place. Oddly there appears not to be any signage so that you know it's a museum or where the entrance is. Also there's a
A pleasant place. We especially liked the porcelain collection. Currently undergoing renovation in preparation for a major exhibition coming soon (Oct 2013).

At the time of our visit the Goya & Picasso gallery was closed for refurbishment as were other parts of the gallery. However there is a wonderful collection of sculpture and classical paintings - worth a visit.

Enjoyed our visit. What a journey through art we had. Lots to see all over this beautiful building. The art is laid out very well. Lots of pieces to keep you focused. The price to get in is reasonable and well priced as you are going to experience the art. Good price in my book.

I visited for a special exhibit, which was very well presented. I especially liked the spacing of the temporary and permanent exhibits; I did not feel crowded and could take my time. Impressive interior. Recommended, perhaps as part of a 2-day visit to Lille.

We were told it was second to the Louvre, it makes me wonder if thats really true. It was small and almost empty in the bottom floor. There were lots if religious paintings, and being from a nonreligious background it wasn't all that interesting to me. It wasn't very orginized

many of the exhibits were missing and none of the explanations for the exhibits were in English - this would be really helpful in order to appreciate the art fully! Staff are stuffy and unhelpful which really spoils the feel of what could be a major attraction for Lille.

The museum has a nice setting, especially at the underground floor (good lighting conditions, good arrangement of works). However, the permanent collection contains average works from lots of periods, but very few ones to make you stay in front of them for more than a couple of
Lots of interesting paintings and sculptures. The museum's entry fee is waived on the first Sunday of each month (€6.00)
The building itself was enormous - you just want to stand and look at the hallway. Going up the stairways made you feel very regal.
My husband and I are not great art lovers but we spent a couple of interesting hours here. Beautiful building with spacious interior and lots of exhibits presented well. Easy to reach on the metro.

It bills itself as the second largest public museum in France after the Louvre - however, the gap between them is very, very large. What impressed me most is their sophisticated audiovisual iPod guiding system, which more museums should adopt.
I'm not keen on religious art, so the first rooms were tedious to me. I only started lighting up when we got to the more modern rooms. Some Rodin sculptures, a van Gogh... Very good!
google: A glimpse of the French history, absolutely fascinating and touching to see a part of History fr different centuries while listening to the beautiful classical music. A must see when visiting Lille. A little trip to the local library …
Very nice and impressive Museum, i was really surprised by it. There are nice things to discover there. They also have this amazing places to sit and enjoy the art, I really liked that.
On Sunday it is free, so we went on a Sunday. Nice experience! Beautiful Building and art

text.wiki:
The Hospice Comtesse or Hospice Notre-Dame is a 17th-century hospice on Rue de la Monnaie in the Old Town area of Lille, France, first built in 1236 by Joan, Countess of Flanders.  It is now a museum on the history of the hospice.
The museum's collections include ceramics, paintings and furniture.


== References ==
text.quote: Hospice built in the 15th-18th centuries, now open as a museum with original furnishings & art.
trip: We stopped by the Musee Hospice Comtesse as part of the walking tour of Lille Old Town. Our tour guide gave an outstanding explanation of the museum, including it purpose.
definitely worth the visit if you are in Lille. building is gorgeous with fantastic history... also very close by to other interesting sites and certainly close to quality shopping area

Whenever visiting towns and cities we like to get a good feel for the history of a place and visiting a museum or two is a good way to do this. Hence we had identified this museum as worth visiting when in Lille. It's a short walk from the town centre. The audit guide is very
This 14th century convent/hospital is well worth a visit and to read about it's very interesting history
This museum was very well done and there were docents all along the way to answer questions. There were wonderful old paintings, and furniture also.

Visited almost by accident after being pointed out by helpful city guide. Well-preserved and laid out old building which opens out into courtyard with several interesting rooms with historical artefacts. Staff are friendly and informative.

The museum is located in the Old Town of Lille on Rue De La Monnaie. It’s about half a mile on foot from the main stations of the town. It is an old hospital which has been rebuilt over the years after a couple of fires. The hospital was run by nuns and you are led through a

In the heart of the old town, this small museum is worth a visit. There are a number of rooms on the ground floor, all furnished in the original style of 16th. And 17th. centuries. Upstairs there is a display of art and artefacts showing the history of Lille from the same

Unusual place to visit -loved the old tiles in the pharmacy - curious interest in bodily functions ( on the far wall on the right above the old toilet), but it was a hospital! Had a sneaky peep in the chapel as the door was left open- amazing roof.

Step back into history as you walk through the hospice that has become a museum to its past. Worth paying the additional 2 euros for an audio guide, especially if you cant read French but also because it provides great back ground information. Currently the church and ward are

Yes, this museum is on the small side, however considering entrance is only €3,70 it is definitely worth a visit. On the ground floor of the museum the exhibits reflect the history of the building showing how it was when it was a hospice. Upstairs is a collection of art works,

Old buildings and displays of Flemish courtly life from centuries back. Many points of interest eg tiles, furniture, herb garden Pity one had to pay extra to see the chapel - oldest part - with excellent roof & paintings, because it was completely taken over by a temporary
Extremely interesting attraction with beautiful interiors. Very good English guide provided on paper.
Initially established as a hospital, this structure now serves as a museum, with interesting collections depicting the lifestyle and historic events from the earlier centuries.

This is was our wet weather option on a school trip, and actually, I’m glad it was raining! The staff were friendly, it was amazing value and the stuff inside was really engaging, especially with the helpful info sheet. A real slice of Flemish life.

We were privileged to see this building with so much history and a very varied art display. Loved the ceilings which appeared to be drapes that had been attached in sections. Make sure you have a Guide.
We had a Lille Card, so went and visited this small museum. We were hoping that it would contain a bit more about the history of Lille and didn't stay very long.

This museum is located in the heart of Lille's old town. It is an interesting building with an interesting history, but the museum itself is not very large. The entrance fee is not excessive and a booklet explaining the history of the building is provided in English. There is

if you are in Lille and would like to discover the history of the city, you must visit this place. It's very well maintained and staff at the entrance in the first room (young, tall, dark hair and with spectacles ) was very knowledgable and welcoming. the walls are covered with

A small museum but very interesting. The entrance fee was E3.70 which included a guide book in 3 languages including English. You can purchase an audio guide for a further E2. The dormitory on the top floor has the history of the town which is also interesting. Great way to

This is a rather small museum, located in the former hospital and monastery, founded in the 13th century. However, none of the original buildings survive, most of the buildings are from the 16th century, but the hall were the needy lived is one of the oldest buildings in Lille.
Really not very much to see. We only stayed half an hour and wouldn't recommend you bother using your time for this.

For a modest fee you can visit this former hospital that was established for orphans by a rich countess centuries ago. You also get a guidebook in 3 languages which explains the history and some of the highlights.
An interesting site which is reasonably priced for admission. We arrived at 10am which is when they open and it was peaceful and quiet at this time.

This was my first stop on my trip to Lille and it definitely is worth a visit! The admission fee is 3.7 euros. There is a very helpful guidebook in 3 languages which explains the history and some of the highlights. The ward was not open for viewing when I was there because an
Audio guide was worth it as gave you the history. Good place to visit and see the goods works they use to do for everyone. Very interesting.

This complex is well worth a visit. It was given to the Town by a worthy benefactress, to act as a hospital for the disadvantaged. It has a charming inner court, and structures of different eras around it. The rooms on the ground floor contain the kitchen (clad in a wonderful
We liked this lttle bit of preserved history, especially the Medieval kitchen and the pharmacy. Modest entrance fee.

You can visit the museum in one hour or so. It was a former hospital managed by a religious order. it has a beautiful collection of Flemish style paintings, old furniture and nicely decorated rooms with dutch tiles. Definitively, the museum you should visit for a short stay in
This old buikding houses a small museum and changing exhibitions. Worth seeing if yo have an hour to spare
This museum is in the centre of the old city and shows the life of the convent which was used as a hospital. A beautiful setting with interesting displays.
Definately a museum well worth visiting. Many interesting displays set in a fabulous building. Staff very freindly and info very good.

We came here after walking past it in one of the cobbled streets. Its only 3.60 entry so well worth it for about an hour. There is a useful guide in English which gives a detailed insight into the history of the rooms in the hospice. The building is in excellent condition and

The museum occupies the site of a medieval hospital and costs EUR 3.60 to go in. After buying tickets in the office to the left of the entrance, you go in to the courtyard and enter the museum through a door on the right. The man on duty there was very helpful and enthusiastic

My wife & I decided to take in some culture while we were in Lille & visited this establishment. We were left pretty non plussed by the experience. Whilst obviously it historically is important to Lille it was not a great attraction for us.
Thoroughly enjoyed my walk through history. Well presented with interesting artifacts. Originally founded in the thirteenth century as a hospital and a hospice.

Interesting museum that is perhaps the only place in Lille that provides a link back to its medieval history when it was controlled by the Counts and Countesses of Flanders. The Countess Jeanne de Flandre founded a hospital in her own palace that remained in use, one way or
A real hidden gem, well worth a visit for say three hours maximum. Very close to the centre so convenient for anyone staying in the City.

text.wiki:
Sébastien Le Prestre de Vauban, Seigneur de Vauban, later Marquis de Vauban (1 May 1633 – 30 March 1707), commonly referred to as Vauban (French: [vobɑ̃]), was a French military engineer, who served under Louis XIV. He is generally considered the greatest engineer of his time, and one of the most important in Western military history.
His principles for fortifications were widely used for nearly 100 years, while aspects of his offensive tactics remained in use until the mid-twentieth century. He worked on many of France's major ports, as well as projects such as the Canal de la Bruche, which remain in use today; his view that all infrastructure had a dual civilian and military function directly inspired the creation of the United States Army Corps of Engineers.
He founded the Corps royal des ingénieurs militaires, the origin of modern French combat engineering units, whose curriculum was based on his publications on engineering design, strategy and training. His economic tract, La Dîme royale, used statistics in support of his arguments, making it a precursor of modern economics. Later destroyed by Royal decree, it contained radical proposals for a more even distribution of the tax burden. His application of rational and scientific methods to problem-solving, whether engineering or social, anticipated an approach common in the Age of Enlightenment.
The most enduring aspect of Vauban's legacy was his view of France as a geographical entity. His advocacy of giving up territory for a more coherent and defensible border was unusual for the period; the boundaries of the French state he proposed in the north and east have changed very little in the four centuries since.


== Biography ==

Sébastien le Prestre de Vauban was born 4 May 1633, in Saint-Léger-de-Foucheret, in the Nièvre, now part of Bourgogne-Franche-Comté. His parents, Urbain le Prestre (ca 1602-1652) and Edmée de Comignolle (?-ca 1651), were members of the minor nobility, from Vauban in Bazoches. His birthplace was renamed Saint-Léger-Vauban by Napoleon III in 1867.

In 1570, his grandfather Jacques acquired Château de Bazoches, when he married Françoise de la Perrière, an illegitimate daughter of the Comte de Bazouches, who died intestate. The 30 year legal battle by the Le Pestre family to retain the property proved financially ruinous, forcing Urbain to become a forestry-worker. He also designed gardens for the local gentry, including the owners of the Château de Ruère, where Vauban spent his early years.In 1660, Vauban married Jeanne d'Aunay d'Epiry (ca 1640-1705); they had two daughters, Charlotte (1661-1709), and Jeanne Françoise (1678-1713), as well as a short-lived infant son. He also had a long-term relationship with Marie-Antoinette de Puy-Montbrun, daughter of an exiled Huguenot officer, usually referred to as 'Mademoiselle de Villefranche.'His only sister Charlotte (1638-1645?) died young, but he had many relatives; his cousin, Paul le Prestre (ca 1630-1703), was an army officer who supervised construction of Les Invalides. Three of Paul's sons served in the army, two of whom were killed in action in 1676 and 1677. The third, Antoine (1654-1731), became Vauban's assistant and later a Lieutenant-General; in 1710, he was appointed Governor of Béthune for life, while he inherited Vauban's titles and the bulk of his lands.Vauban died in Paris on 30 March 1707; buried near his home in Bazoches, his grave was destroyed during the French Revolution. In 1808, Napoléon Bonaparte ordered his heart reburied in Les Invalides, resting place for many of France's most famous soldiers.


== Career ==

The first half of the 17th century in France was dominated by domestic conflict and foreign wars, including the Huguenot rebellions of the 1620s, the 1635–1659 Franco-Spanish War, and 1648 to 1653 Fronde. Vauban's family was one of many impacted by these events; his Catholic grandfather married a Protestant from La Rochelle, and served Huguenot leader Admiral Coligny, while two of his uncles died in the war with Spain.At the age of ten, Vauban was sent to the Carmelite college in Semur-en-Auxois, where he was taught the basics of mathematics, science, and geometry. His father's work was also relevant; the design of neo-classical gardens and fortifications were closely linked, since they both concerned managing space. It was common to combine these skills; John Armstrong (1674–1742), Marlborough's chief military engineer, laid out the lake and gardens at Blenheim Palace.In 1650, Vauban joined the household of his local magnate, the Prince de Condé, where he met de Montal; a close neighbour from Nièvre, the two were colleagues for many years, and often worked together. During the 1650–1653 Fronde des nobles, Condé was arrested by the Regency Council, led by Louis XIV's mother Anne of Austria and Cardinal Mazarin. After being released in 1652, he and his supporters, among them Vauban and de Montal, went into exile in the Spanish Netherlands, and allied with the Spanish.Vauban worked on the defences of Sainte-Menehould, one of Condé's principal possessions. While doing so, he was captured by a Royalist patrol in early 1653, and switched sides, serving in the force led by Louis Nicolas de Clerville that took Sainte-Meenhould in November. Clerville, later appointed Commissaire general des fortifications, employed him on siege operations, and building fortifications. Vauban was appointed Ingénieur du Roi or Royal Engineer in 1655, and by the time the war with Spain ended in 1659, he was known as a talented engineer of energy and courage.

Under the terms of the Treaty of the Pyrenees, Spain ceded much of French Flanders, and Vauban was put in charge of fortifying newly-acquired towns such as Dunkirk. This pattern of French territorial gains, followed by fortification of new strongpoints, was followed in the 1667–1668 War of Devolution, 1672–1678 Franco-Dutch War and 1683-1684 War of the Reunions. In the course of his career, Vauban supervised or designed the building of more than 300 separate fortifications,   and by his own estimate, supervised more than 40 sieges from 1653 to 1697.The first of these was the 1673 siege of Maastricht, although he was subordinate to Louis, who ranked as the senior officer present, and thus took credit for its capture. Vauban was rewarded with a large sum of money, which he used to purchase the Château de Bazouches from his cousin in 1675.Post-1673, French strategy in Flanders was based on a memorandum from Vauban to Louvois, Minister of War, setting out a proposed line of fortresses known as the Ceinture de fer, or iron belt (see Map). He was made Maréchal de camp in 1676, and succeeded Clerville as Commissaire general des fortifications in 1677.During the Nine Years War, he supervised the capture of Namur in 1692, the major French achievement of the war, while the 1697 siege of Ath is often considered his offensive masterpiece. He was rewarded with money, and made Comte de Vauban, a member of the Order of the Holy Spirit and Order of Saint Louis, and an Honorary Member of the French Academy of Sciences.The numbers needed to conduct a siege, and prevent interference from opponents meant armies of the Nine Years' War often exceeded 100,000 men, sizes unsustainable for pre-industrial societies. It prompted a change in tactics, Marlborough arguing winning one battle was more beneficial than taking 12 fortresses. The armies of the War of the Spanish Succession averaged around 35,000, and siege warfare superseded by a greater emphasis on mobility.

Vauban was promoted Maréchal de France in 1703, marking the end of his military career, although the Ceinture de fer proved its worth after the French defeat at Ramillies in 1706. Under pressure from superior forces on multiple fronts, France's northern border remained largely intact despite repeated efforts to break it. Capturing Lille cost the Allies 12,000 casualties and most of the 1708 campaigning season; the lack of progress between 1706–1712 enabled Louis to reach an acceptable deal at Utrecht in 1713, as opposed to the humiliating terms presented in 1707.With more leisure time, Vauban developed a broader view of his role. His fortifications were designed for mutual support, so they required connecting roads, bridges and canals; garrisons needed to be fed, so he prepared maps showing the location of forges, forests, and farms. Since these had to be paid for, he developed an interest in tax policy, and in 1707 published La Dîme royale, documenting the economic misery of the lower classes. His solution was a flat 10% tax on all agricultural and industrial output, and eliminating the exemptions which meant most of the nobility and clergy paid nothing. Although confiscated and destroyed by Royal decree, the use of statistics to support his arguments ... establishes him as a founder of modern economics, and precursor of the Enlightenment's socially concerned intellectuals.


== Doctrines and legacy ==


=== Offensive doctrines; siege warfare ===

While his modern fame rests on the fortifications he built, Vauban's greatest innovations were in offensive operations, an approach he summarised as 'More powder, less blood.' Initially reliant on existing concepts, he later adapted these on lines set out in his memorandum of March 1672, Mémoire pour servir à l'instruction dans la conduite des sièges.In this period, sieges became the dominant form of warfare; during the 1672–1678 Franco-Dutch War, three battles were fought in the Spanish Netherlands, of which only Seneffe was unrelated to a siege. Their importance was heightened by Louis XIV, who viewed them as low-risk opportunities for demonstrating his military skill and increasing his prestige; he was present at 20 of those conducted by Vauban.The 'siege parallel' had been in development since the mid-16th century but Vauban brought the idea to practical fulfilment at Maastricht in 1673. Three parallel trenches were dug in front of the walls, the earth thus excavated being used to create embankments screening the attackers from defensive fire, while bringing them as close to the assault point as possible (see Diagram). Artillery was moved into the trenches, allowing them to target the base of the walls at close range, with the defenders unable to depress their own guns enough to counter this; once a breach had been made, it was then stormed. This approach was used in offensive operations well into the 20th century.However, Vauban adapted his approach to the situation, and did not use the siege parallel again until Valenciennes in 1677. Always willing to challenge accepted norms, at Valenciennes, he proposed assaulting the breach during the day, rather than at night as was normal practice. He argued this would reduce casualties by surprising the defenders, and allow better co-ordination among the assault force; he was supported by Louis, and the attack proved successful.Vauban made several innovations in the use of siege artillery, including ricochet firing, and concentrating on specific parts of the fortifications, rather than targeting multiple targets. His Dutch rival Menno van Coehoorn employed a similar approach. While the 'Van Coehoorn method' sought to overwhelm defences with massive firepower, such as the Grand Battery of 200 guns at Namur in 1695, Vauban preferred a more gradual approach. Both had their supporters; Vauban argued his was less costly in terms of casualties, but it took more time, an important consideration in an age when far more soldiers died from disease than in combat.


=== Defensive doctrines; fortifications ===

It was accepted even the strongest fortifications would fall, given time; the process was so well understood by the 1690s, betting on the length of a siege became a popular craze. As few states could afford large standing armies, defenders needed time to mobilise; to provide this, fortresses were designed to absorb the attackers' energies, similar to the use of crumple zones in modern cars. The French defence of Namur in 1695 showed "how one could effectively win a campaign, by losing a fortress, but exhausting the besiegers."As with the siege parallel, the strength of Vauban's defensive designs was his ability to synthesise and adapt the work of others to create a more powerful whole. His first works used the 'star-shape' or bastion fort design, also known as the trace Italienne, based on the designs of Antoine de Ville (1596–1656), and Blaise Pagan (1603–1665). His subsequent 'systems' strengthened their internal works with the addition of casemated shoulders and flanks.The principles of Vauban's 'second system' were set out in the 1683 work Le Directeur-Général des fortifications, and used at Landau and Mont-Royal, near Traben-Trarbach; both were advanced positions, intended as stepping-off points for French offensives into the Rhineland. Located 200 metres (660 ft) above the Moselle, Mont-Royal had main walls 30 metres (98 ft) high, 3 kilometres (1.9 mi) long and space for 12,000 troops; this enormously expensive work was demolished when the French withdrew after the 1697 Treaty of Ryswick, and only the foundations remain today. Fort-Louis was another new construction, built on an island in the middle of the Rhine; this allowed Vauban to combine his defensive principles with town planning, although like Mont-Royal, little of it remains.The French retreat from the Rhine after 1697 required new fortresses; Neuf-Brisach was the most significant, designed on Vauban's 'third system', and completed after his death by Louis de Cormontaigne. Using ideas from Fort-Louis, this incorporated a regular square grid street pattern inside an octagonal fortification; tenement blocks were built inside each curtain wall, strengthening the defensive walls and shielding more expensive houses from cannon fire.To create a more coherent border, Vauban advocated destroying poor fortifications, and relinquishing territory that was hard to defend. In December 1672, he wrote to Louvois: "I am not for the greater number of places, we already have too many, and please God we had half of that, but all in good condition!" 


=== Infrastructure and engineering ===
 
While often overlooked, Vauban worked on many civilian infrastructure projects, including rebuilding the ports of Brest, Dunkerque and Toulon. Since his fortifications were designed for mutual support, roads and waterways were an essential part of their design, such as the Canal de la Bruche, a 20-kilometre (12 mi) canal built in 1682 to transport materials for the fortification of Strasbourg. He also provided advice on the repair and enlargement of the Canal du Midi in 1686.His holistic approach to urban planning, which integrated city defences with layout and infrastructure, is most obvious at Neuf-Brisach. His legacy is recognised in the Vauban district in Freiburg, developed as a model for sustainable neighbourhoods post-1998.Vauban's 'scientific approach' and focus on large infrastructure projects strongly influenced American military and civil engineering and inspired the creation of the US Corps of Engineers in 1824. Until 1866, West Point's curriculum was modelled on that of the French Ecole Polytechnique, and designed to produce officers with skills in engineering and mathematics.To ensure a steady supply of skilled engineers, in 1690 Vauban established the Corps royal des ingénieurs militaires; until his death, candidates had to pass an examination administered by Vauban himself. Many of his publications, including Traité de l'attaque des places, and Traité des mines, were written at the end of his career to provide a training curriculum for his successors.


== Assessment ==

Vauban's offensive tactics remained relevant for centuries; his principles were clearly identifiable in those used by the Việt Minh at Dien Bien Phu in 1954. His defensive fortifications dated far more quickly, partly due to the enormous investment required; Vauban himself estimated that in 1678, 1694 and 1705, between 40 and 45% of the French army was assigned to garrison duty.Vauban's reputation meant his designs remained in use long after developments in artillery made them obsolete, for example the Dutch fort of Bourtange, built in 1742. The Corps des ingénieurs militaires was based on his teachings; between 1699 and 1743, only 631 new candidates were accepted, the vast majority relatives of existing or former members. As a result, French military engineering became ultra-conservative, while many 'new' works used his designs, or professed to do so, such as those built by Louis de Cortmontaigne at Metz in 1728–1733. This persisted into the late 19th century; Fort de Queuleu, built in 1867 near Metz, is recognisably a Vauban-style design.Some French engineers continued to be innovators, notably the Marquis de Montalembert, who published La Fortification perpendiculaire in 1776. A rejection of the principles advocated by Vauban and his successors, his ideas became the prevailing orthodoxy in much of Europe, but were dismissed in France.
