If you are in the Ypres area it is a must to stay to take part in the evening memorial service. This is carried out at 8 p.m. every day inside the Menin gate itself. When we were there there was a band playing, a bugler sounding the Last Post and Reveille and a choir singing.

Such a great place to visit, make sure you get there at about 7 (1900) so you can get a good spot to view the ceremony, the last post always brings a tear to my eye, we also managed to find my wife’s great, great uncle Stanley and one of the panels

We have visited here for 10yrs plus and always attend last post whilst here. It is the most moving tribute I can imagine. My grandfather served during WW1 and to remember him and those who he served amongst is truly humbling.
The ceremony runs every night and is a testimony to the people who live there to their everlasting gratitude for the sacrifices of those who came to their aid. A respectful tribute.

Be there early to get a good view... we arrived at 7.15pm and lots already there for The Last Post. I easily found my relative on the memorial which is almost unbelievable to see the names of so many young people who died in the war and who have no grave. It is now 7.55pm and
This is something you must see if you are anywhere near Ypres. Plus take the Ramparts Walk and hear the Last Post
You can not help but be moved by this memorial. The last post ceremony takes place at 8pm every night. Also very moving.... gets very packed.

The moving 8pm memorial service is a must for all those who would like the opportunity to honour the memories of the many named but not buried dead of the WW1. The setting is itself of interest and if you have the chance walk the city walls. Not only will you go back to 1600
a must see if your in the area on a sat night the who town seemed to be there it was such a lovely evening
It’s fantastic that the last post is played every night and brilliant to stand with an international group of people enjoying the peace our ancestors paid such a high price to secure for us.

This was our second visit, but the first for our children. It bears the name of one close family member and those of a few more distant relatives. This imposing structure has stood in this prominent position for over 90 years, and is the site of the amazing nightly memorial

It was our privilege to participate in this ceremony. Pa Barry Olsen’s Karakia and the ode were read in Te reo Maori - himine from Ngāti Rānana and our flax and fern wreath we’re laid to remember our sons from Aotearoa New Zealand. Ka maumahara tonu tātou ki a rātou

It's understandable why this is the No1 thing to do in Ypres. It's the most moving rememberance service you'll ever see. Starts at 8 every night, however get there for 7.30 if you want a good viewing spot. The buglers are from the Fire Service, immaculate in their uniforms and

The gateway into Ypres is the Menin Gate memorial, park in the centre and then go have a walk through, up and around, a truly lovely piece of architecture and in true honour of the losses of war, moving, simply and must visit.

I would like to thank all those who make the last post at 8pm every evening available they do a fantastic job. Menin Gate Memorial, is very moving seeing so many names of men who have never been found who gave their lives in the service of this country, many are Commonwealth

Very moving experience. The last post makes you think twice about all that happened. Today a group from New Zealand performed the haka. That was amazing in itself. Combined where it was made it even more special.
Together with some friends we decided to visit the memorial and were very moved by the last post and wreath laying ceremony. Hugely recommended
a reverent place to visit marked by the brave soles who allow us the freedoms of today a must see i wish i could have stayed until 8pm for the last post we will be comming back to see this soon
Visit at all times of the day for a different experience. When it is quiet, early morning or late evening, an experience that will never be forgotten.

Will keep this simple as you can see the other reviews. advice, get there early for the last post. Try and vist the war graves nearby, follow the path on the right when you go to the top of the Menin gate. They offtern get over looked, not a long walk, but not a short one either

I cannot recommend this highly enough- please go if you are in the area in the evening. These volunteers come every night to honour our veterans from Commonwealth countries that served during World War One. It is important to show up early. I understand 7:30 is okay most days,
Well to be honest this is great to see, but you have to be tall or be there early. Starts at 20:00 but people start gathering from 19:15.
Impressive monument in honour of too many commonwealth soldiers who lost their lives in WWI. Last Post bugle memorial service at 8pm every evening.

There are 55,000 names of the missing on this incredible memorial. You find yourself looking for your family name. Half hoping you find it. Half hoping you can’t. A very respectful construction in a beautiful town

It is something to be remembered of: The Ceremony of the Fallen true Heroes.. Respect and most of all the beauty that there is this Ceremony to understand and share what had happened in the First World War.

Attended the last Post Ceremony recently, it was absolutely beautiful. I was delighted that the Last Post Association allowed us to lay a wreath of Irish Native Laurel to remember all those Proud Irish Men whom made the ultimate sacrifice during the battles of Ypres, in
Such an inspiration to be there. It takes a long time to realize how many men lost their lives and were never found.

The Menin Gate was built (out of a medieval bridge) with help from the Commonwealth War Graves Commission in the 1927. Outside rhe city there are the Lions on guard. The walls inside commemorate the 54 plus thousand Commonwealth troops who 'went missing' in the WW1 battles to
Atmospheric and beautiful memorial. The last post ceremony is every night at 8pm. Get there by 7 if you want to see anything. Take time to look around the names and go for a walk through the wood.

A beautiful but sad place. All these men disappeared with out a trace. Lost in the mud without a grave. The Fire bridges nightly Last Post is a sad and moving tribute to the fallen. Go early and look for the white circle of pavers in the middle of the road. This marks were they
Well worth the visit here, puts the sacrifice into perspective. Ensure that you attend the last post ceremony held every evening at 8pm, wonderful to see so many people attending
I’d seen on TV, I thought I understood, I thought I accepted the scale of the waste. And then you marvel at the loss.
I was blown away by this place & with all the names on the walls I can highly recommend a visit & try to be there for the last post at 8PM
Every night large amount of people gather around the gate to pay their respects to the gallant and brave soldiers, who gave up their lives so others could live in peace.
Beautiful gate, on beautiful fortress route. The amount of names really only starts giving you an impression of what happened here.
Our band, Reading Scottish Pipe Band played during the Last Post ceremony on the 27th April 2019. It was a very moving and meaningful event.

Again the presence of a Scots Band made the occasion and out front view was a bonus. Very respectful crowd and the buglers were top quality. Really well organised and wheelchair access thoughtfully arranged.

Very moving event, would recommend this to anyone visiting Ypres. Get there early if you want a good view, if you are lucky there will be some military personnel on parade but the last post is performed by the local fire service.

It is great to see how the tradition of the Last Post is being maintained for over a century. Every night over the last century, the ceremony is performed, with special performances on the weekends or special days. We witnessed it with a Pipes and Drums band, and that truely

Have visited the Menin Gate on a few occasions and it never fails to impress. It is a very thought provoking memorial to the thousands of people who lost their lives in the war. Thousands of inscriptions on the walls of those who died.
Beautiful Anzac Day ceremony. The Menin gate is a place I always wanted to return to. I went as a child and it’s always stuck with me. It was awesome to return on ANZAC day.
Lovely ceremony and very moving. Gets very busy so get there early if you want to be able to see. Starts at 8.00 but need to get there about 7.00.

On March 12, 2019 we went on school excursion to Ypres in the framework of our history class about the Great War. As you might know, the fighting during WWI, that took place from 1914 until 1918, was very fierce in the Belgian Westhoek. Tens of thousands of patriotic and
I have been wanting to visit here for quite some time. So glad I did. Many many thoughts evoked during the service. It should be a must for everyone.

Five friends and I visited the menin gate on 7th April to see the last post which we did , it was very well organised and we found it very moving, I must mention the British school children that were in attendance that night they behaved impeccably throughout and were a credit

This gate is covered with so many names of the fallen soldiers. It was a very emotional visit. So many young people died with their dreams, plans, aspirations. Every single live shortened by this Great War. If you have chance stay until 8pm for the Last Post. This is a “must

This gate is a short walk from the center of town. This gate marks where the soldiers left this town for the trenches and battlefields. Upon the walls are etched the names of nearly 55,000 soldiers who perished but whose bodies were never found. To this day, at 8 pm every

Stayed on the local campsite within 5 minutes from the gate. The Last Post service beging on the hour of 8pm. Crowds gather from 7.30 to secure the best place near the from but if you just close your eyes and listen it is enough. I'm not ashamed to say we were very emotional
You must visit the Menin Gate Memorial. Very Impressed building. Very clean. For the Last Post you must get there early about 45 mins for advice.
Very busy but worthwhile going, if you want to see everything happening you will need to pick a spot about 30minutes before the ceremony starts at 8pm.
I'm here once a year and have been for the last 10 years every summer...this time i was with friends who'd never been and were all genuinely moved by the ceremony....if you've not been..Why not?

This is a superb monument bridging one of the main roads into Ypres central. Obviously aware of the human tragedy that is War and in particular the First World War. I wanted to see this memorial and was not disappointed in it’s structure, appearance and build quality. With

whilst driving into ypres i was supprised that we drove through the menin gate, the memorial is a magnificent piece of art, the sad thing is all the names on the memorial are for soldiers that have never been found

The last post ceremony is a highlight of any trips to the Salient and this proved to be the case in this trip. I’ve been coming here for nearly 40 years and on many occasions it’s been myself and my mate and the fire brigade volunteers - intimate is not a descriptive enough
A beautiful place to visit. At 8pm every evening there is a short Last Post service to remember the fallen heroes of the Great War. Very emotional. Every person should visit this once in their life.

My Wife and I attended this very moving ceremony with the laying of 2 Wreaths for the Rennie family in memory of 2 Great Uncles both of whom were killed in WW1. A Experience we will NEVER forget. Also to view the 54,000 names inscribed inside the Memorial is very sobering.
If you come to look at the gate or see the service its a must visit place in Ypres. So moving its hard to describe. Ive brought people here and seen them in tears. Please, Please visit.
Very moving to see how many wreaths and flowers are placed here every day. Good that lots of school trips visit. Important that those who died are never forgotten.
Watched the ceremony at 8 at night. Big respect for the fallen. Platoons of young soldiers watching and marching from the scene.

We arrived for a Saturday night ceremony, the Menin Gate fills up very quickly from 19:15 onwards for a 20:00 ceremony so I would recommend getting there early. The Gate itself is beautiful, and takes your breath away when you realise the sheer number of names that are engraved

A very moving ceremony. Amazed at the size of the crowd many of whom are locals. Thank you to the people of Ypres for the respect shown on a nightly basis. The actual gate really brings home the cost to the British Commonwealth of WW1.

Wow, what a place to visit. We only had a morning in Ypres & went straight to the memorial gate & spent a long time looking at all the names. I wish we could have been there at 8pm when they played ‘The Last Post’. We will definitely come back.
I have visited the Menin Gate on several occasions and it will never cease to amaze me, A beautiful structure and symbol, well looked after and a must for anyone to visit.

We were very lucky to be there on the night an 80 piece orchestra from Antwerp provided the music for the ceremony. They were outstanding. We were advised to be there early as the space within the gate fills quickly - the wait was certainly worth doing. This is definitely a MUST
Beautiful memorial to the 54.000 service men who were never found and buried, every name is on it very moving to see.

We visited Ypres on a very cold January weekend but was amazed at how many people turned up for the last post at 8pm. This was on my list of things to do and loved it’s poigniancy. So glad I made the effort. Ypres itself is lovely with plenty to see and do for such a small place

This must be one of the most iconic sites from the WW1 Battlefields. Inscribed with more than 54k names of those soldiers missing in the Ypres Salient. A beautiful memorial designed by Bloomfield and location for the nightly Last Post Service. The road closes around the memorial
Visited on several occasions. Make sure you can witness the last post at 8pm. They will always be remembered.
Every day at 8pm the Last Post is played, get there early if want to stand in a good spot to see what is going on.

This is a wonderful place built in memory of those who lost their lives in the First World war. It is a place that is a must visit for all ages and in particular young people. It shows the importance of Peace in our world
This place is highly interesting because of the first world war. It is mreover easy to find when in Ieer.
Well worth a visit. Names of thousands or war dead beautifully carved all over the monument. Well cared for and host to last post ceremony every evening. Great way to pay respects.

We visited the gate initially for the last post but then came back the next day. As a piece of architecture, it's stunning in itself but the sheer vastness of the volume of names carved into the walls that represent young men who were lost without trace during World War I
Visiting the Menin Gate is a very humbling experience and I think everyone should go once in their lifetime
The enormity of this beautiful structure allows you to fully absorb the loss encountered during the Great War.

The memorial is extremely impressive, and is covered inside and out with 1000's of names. The list is staggering and really brings home the sheer waste of all those men's lives. Cars drive through the monument, and its more atmospheric there on a Sunday morning when there's less
Pay your respects and go. It is amazing to see and very emotional. It can get busy so get there at least half an hour before it starts at 8pm

Immense memorial whose size benefits the sacrifice made by so many. Please walk through the gate away from the town square to see the wrought iron poppies forged by children and the 2 new lions. best view of the Gate. CWGC information is excellent. Pls note the CWGC office has

I have long wanted to visit the Menin Gate and was not dissappointed, but I was stunned. Stunned by its sheer enormity and the tens of thousands of names carved into the plaques. Those poor souls who lost their lives and the obvious emotion that is seen as people take in this
So touching but get there early to get a good view of the Last Post musicians. Take time to go up the stairs & look around. A good entry point for The Ramparts.
Very emotional visit to the Menin Gate Memorial. Thank you to the people of Ypres for looking after the memories so beautifully.
A must see if you are in the area. A striking symbol of WW1 and it's legacy. A few signboards to read and pretty parkland either side. Very close to the town centre of Ypres.

This should not be regraded as a tourist attraction but a tribute to those soldiers who had no known grave. In combination with the War Graves Cemeteries, it brings home the massive sarifice made bt our predecessors.
What a fantastic tribute to those lost souls, the gate had been so well attended for the last 90 years and it should be a place all school children from around the world must attend.

Get to the Ypres Bar at 7.30 pm and get yourself a swift drink and then step outside for the Last Post Ceremony every night at 8.00pm. Very moving and always well attended with weekends being extremely busy.

Arrived for the day around lunchtime. Local Saturday market was just closing up and tourists had not yet arrived. So was still quiet around the main square. Walking up the the memorial was inspiring and to see the thousands of names carved in the stonework was amazing.

We arrived at 18.00 and took time to walk the gate looking at the thousand upon thousand of names who are still missing . We took our places and waited in the absolute silence . The local fire brigade, who play the last post marched into position looking absolutely immaculate .
Each night at 8pm she them play the bugles and people laying wreathes down. A large number of people came out on the Saturday night that we visited.

Every evening at 8.00pm the last post ceremony takes place at the Menin Gate. It's an unmissable experience commemorating those who lost their lives in the conflicts in WW1 in Flanders fields. It will stay with you long after you've left.

Ok it is not the Great Wall of china but what a great and respectful monument to those who gave so much for us, today. I would recommend visiting during the day and looking around in slow time at the names from across the globe. It is then a sobering parade at 8pm when the last
A place everyone should visit to appreciate the sacrifice those before us made. Really powerful and thought provoking.

You actually drive through this gate as you come into Ypres and it’s absolutely huge. It’s all very clean too. You can browse along the names or you can climb up some steps in the middle (on both sides) and go into the park area on either side

We have visited Ieper many times and always visit the Menin Gate at least once during our visits. Depending on the time of the year the Last Post ceremony can get very busy and you need to arrive early to get a space. We chose to walk an indirect route via the Kazematten

We visited this thought provoking memorial to pay our respects to those men and women who gave their lives to protect Europe and change the face of history. It is totally mind blowing to see the list of regiments and names inscribed on the monument and is hard to comprehend the

Myself and a couple of friends had walked to this memorial as part of a sponsored walk, visiting the commonwealth graves along the western front and paying are respects. This ended with being at the menin gate ceremony on the 11th November 2018 to comerate, 100 years since the

This is such a moving experience. Tens of thousands of soldiers with no known resting place are named on every facet of the monument. It's a very impressive building straddling the river and set in lawns and gardens. At 8 pm members of the local brigade play the Last Post as

Memorable so many names haunting Impressive the surrounding gardens and river a must and do not miss the Flander Musium so worth the time. what occured just over a hundred years ago must not be forgotten or repeated
This is a must for any traveller when visiting this location. A very moving memory to go and see. You cant be disappointed.

My husband and I attended a ceremony one evening. It was very moving and there were so many people which added to the atmosphere. The buglers were awesome and the sound echoed around the gate. Extraordinary.

We visited twice - once to see the memorial, and once for the nightly ceremony. The memorial is designed as a Roman triumphal arch, and displays the names of the nearly 55,000 soldiers of the (then) British Empire who were missing in action, up until 16 August 1917. These are

Magnificent tribute to the fifty thousand + soldiers of the commonwealth troops who gave their life. Very sad to see all those names and many of them would have been no more kids !! Nice to see the high standard of maintenance and support by the commonwealth to keep this looking
It is incredible that they kept this tradition going every night. A definite must see. Try to be there a bit before 20:00 at night to get a better view.

Probably the main reason why you would visit Ypres, but if it’s not you must. Beautifully presented and emotionally inspiring when you read just a few of the 54,000 names! The last post was very moving.

The Menin Gate Memorial is a rather huge but imposing building. It is in a way a metaphor for the huge sacrifice of those who gave their lives for peace and of the debt we and those after us, owe to the fallen. More than 50 000 names are on the walls of the Menin Gate. It is
Very moving seeing all the names. Very well maintained and truly worth seeing. Daily rememberance memorial carried out in tribute to the fallen.

Well laid out with names of the war heroes from around the world. Poppies have been put by some of the names denoting that they have been found and visited by their family. On the stairs are metal structures so you can lay wreaths. However, if you see the Last Post you can be
Menin Gate is a must see in Ypres. It has a relaxing atmosphere although a sad history. Ypres is a very friendly place.
Beautiful old town restored after the horrors of war and welcoming people. Interesting sites to remind us of the sacrifices made.

Visited it twice in November. Once for the Last Post ceremony and two days later for the 100th Anniversary of the end of WW1. Both great experiences. The 'Gate' itself is a great memorial to the soldiers who have no known gravesite. The names on the walls, their countries and

I had previously visited in 2016 for the first time and watched two Last Post ceremonies, each very moving. This was surpassed in November 2018, when the choir I belong to had the honour of singing at the ceremony. The whole experience was very reverent and solemn and it was
Take some time to visit this impressive Great War monument, make sure to climb the stairs to visit the small replica. Be there well before 8PM for the Last Post ceremony, played every day.

We walked down from the main sqaure to visit the gate - it was drizzling and overall miserable but the memorial to the young that died in the first world war made us put that all into perspective - the sheer futility and the massive loss of life is reflected by the columns and
Inspiring!!! The number of names of those who have no known grave reveals the magnitude and futility of war.

We came here to find the name of our relative who died during the Second Battle of Ypres and whose body was never found. It was a comfort to find his name inscribed on the wall. Wreaths were still in place from Armistice day, which made it more special.
The Menin Gate is an incredible monument. I was stunned by the Last Post ceremony that happens each night and the emotion involved. Definitely one to witness.
Impressive monument to remember the First World War. Each day at 20.00 o’clock sharp they perform the Last Post. It’s the closest thing you can get to the First World War.
Having found our relative on the walls a of this incredible monument, we look forward to the 8pm Las Post. There may he tears. Could not visit stores without seeing this.

I have visited before but took the wife to see the memorial,it’s only an hour from Calais. Very sombre. Would recommend a visit to anyone. Have a look at all the people who lost lives and are still unaccounted for.
What an incredible place. In awe of the amount of names of soldiers with no burial grave. Must be visited once in your lifetime at least to pay your respects. Make sure you go up both sides.
seeing this was amazing, the names on the walls and the garden beside it was just beautiful. the respect I have for this place! people who give there tomorrow so I could have my today!

This is somewhere you have to visit during your time at Ypres. I walked around the Menin Gate during the day and then I went back an hour before the last post. I recommend going in plenty of time to be able to see. Very touching and a beautiful memorial for the heroes of the

After arriving in Ypres to start our journey following in my Grandfathers footsteps in WW1, the Menen Gate was our first stop after we arrived in Ypres, and then again later for the Last Post Ceremony.....I very moving/ sobering place to visit to pay homage to those whose names
Who could not be moved to tears by this beautiful memorial and the evening ceremony. Such respect and commitment from the Belgium fire brigade. You should be very proud.

The Lions that were donated to Australia at the end of the war as a gift to Australia were lent back to the town for celebration and copies were made to take the place of the original that are now back in Canberra.

Anyone can apply to lay a wreath at one of the 8pm ceremonies that have run every night for 90 years at this extraordinary memorial, thanks to the dedication of the Town's volunteers, including the buglers who play Last Post and a version of Reveille. On this evening there were

This is def a place to visit, especially for 8pm. Every night at 8pm, Ypres puts on the Last Man Post, 365 days a yr. This is to remember the men and women who fought in the wars. very moving ceremony. The gate is amazing and with all the names of the last solders on the walls,

The Menin gate is a wonderful tribute to the lives lost in WW1. We arrived early to see the last post which is recommended as it gets very busy. It's a very moving ceremony and a must do. Allow plenty of time to walk around the memorial and take it all in.

This is an incredibly moving place to visit. A fantastic building in itself but a fitting memorial to those war dead who have no known grave. If your loved one was lost in WW1 without a known grave then you need to visit the Menin Gate.
Very nice area to visit and to experience the mass of names commerated on this memorial, and the last post is preformed each evening, it is also very close to the centre of town and museums
Stumbled upon this memorial (was not planning in visiting ieper). Didn’t realize the sacrifice of others.
Absolutely worth the visit. Ypres itself is an amazing place with very friendly people and shop owners. The market square is great to.

Visited to experience and pay respect for the Last Post to remember the fallen, An honour to have visited it. Last Post is at 8pm but get there early as its well attended every day by not just visitors but local also, Respect!
Where the fallen are remembered. A place to return to year after year. An honour to be in the presence of souls lost to War. We shall remember them.
Even though the Last Post is signalled at 8pm, get there earlier to walk around the memorial. Its very moving. At the time we went, there was a large area of 'poppies' displayed - very moving
Privileged to see this for the first time at the 100 year memorial weekend for armistice. First post at 6am was a special moment as were the poppies above on the walkable walls.

It's almost impossible not to visit the memorial as it is literally the gate to the city centre. Seeing all the names of the fallen heroes is quite impressive and confronting at the same time. Every night at 8 PM you can stay to hear The Last Post being played.

Certainly busy on most nights come rain or shine but a good place to remember those who gave the highest price for peace. Very moving. Close to centre and flat walking. Lasts around 8 mins and be there 15 mins before.
Watched the sounding of the last post at 8pm. Well worth waiting in the cold for!! Arrive at least 20 mins early if you want a front row view!

My Wife.s Grandfather fought on the Ypres Salient and lost his hand. Fortunately, he survived after extended stays in Hospitals in France and the UK. We wanted to visit this location to remember him. When we arrived early, even on a damp grey evening in November, we found it

The Last Post is played at 20.00 hrs and it is important to get there at least 30 mins before to get a good view. It will only last about 15 mins. I think the best place is at the opposite end to where they play as you have an uninterrupted view.

This is not an attraction. This is a pilgrimage site. The crowds from night to night vary as does your experience of it. By day, it is often quiet, but be aware that traffic passes through the middle. Young children may have difficulty understanding the significance of the site,
If we forget the lessons of history, then history will be repeated. The thousands of names inscribed on every section of the gate should remind us as to the sacrifices made and the horrors of war.

Very moving. The respectful hush (save the odd coughs from the crowd) is humbling, as people share their silent respect while the Last Post is being played and wreaths layed by schoold and other organisations. This is worth the trip to Ypres, on its own! Get there for 07:30 in

We reached the gate in a misty afternoon, when entering the gate you can see all the memorial plates beautifully arranged on the walls. If you climb upstairs you have a beautiful view upon the water channel surrounding the old city

All children should visit this place to realise sacrifices made for them by previous generations. The act of remembrance that takes place EVERY night at 8pm ,where The Last Post is played, should not be missed.
We had been to the ceremony many years ago and found it just as moving this time. A must if staying in the Ypres area.
Stopped by to pay our respects. Felt very humbled by the enormity of the sacrifice displayed, so many young soldiers without graves to lay flowers at. Nothing more to say.
Beautifull memorial dedicated to all who lost their lives in the Great War. A bit busy because of a street passing through it and a lot of visitors. Free access.
Go early if possible to miss the school parties. A great location to commemorate the allied armies defence of Ypres but at such a cost...

The nightly 8.00pm service is a must & we did consecutive nights of the memorial bugle call commemorating the end of WW1 Try and get there at least 30 min earlier for a good viewing as it could get quite full
What else can you say it is so moving being at Menin Gate at 8...but otherwise... well it is a place of sadness and reflection. A must visit.

The original lions are back in Australia, but replicas have been commissioned and sit proudly on the plinths. The memorial was awash with poppies, with it being the weekend after the 100th anniversary.
The names on the Menin gate make such pointless loss so real. It is worth walking behind into the galleries and up onto the ramparts
You can’t fail to be impressed by the sheer quality of this magnificent monument to all those who lost their lives in the Great War.
An amazing memorial to the thousands of brave men who died fighting for our freedoms. When you view all the names it brings into focus the sacrifices these men made for our freedoms.

This was one of the highlights of our battlefield tour. We had planned ahead and were granted permission to lay a wreath at the memorial. Three of our group presented the wreath which we purchased for about $20 USD. The ceremony lasts about 20 minutes, is solemn, very well
A sobering visit to an immense monument. Our time of visit did clash with a number of school trips, so was not particularly quiet.

Visiting the Menin gate during the day before the daily evening service was very moving. You are made to realise the appalling scale of lost lives from all over the world. It is carefully crafted to remind us of 60,000 young men whose bodies were never found and who are

Moving experience at the menin gate Ypres 11th November 2018. 100 year Armistice / Remembrance , every person should take the time to visit Ypres for the last post at the menin gate. Visit the graves of the fallen and pay their respects to all the men young and old , who gave

An easy place to find from the market place about 400yds away. An imposing immaculate structure, but busy with traffic going through it. Hundreds of wreaths( at the time of writing 14th Nov) and individual poppies making a spectacular, colourful memorial but also incredibly sad
This moving memorial is nothing other than a must visit. I recommend we all visit this memorial once on our life.
very moving experience to participate in or attend. it can ce crowed , best tip is wait outside the gate till the close the traffic , then you can get a good vantage to see all

A very emotional time as the 100th anniversary of the signing of the Armistice. I joined the march and laid a wreath in memory of my Great Uncle and his comrades who were killed with him on the Somme. Memorable in every way.

A visit to the Menin Gate in Ypres/Ieper was an essential part of our Armistice Centenary commemorations weekend. It is a moving tribute to those lost during the Great War. A must see and thought provoking.

Once again the Menin Gate Memorial looked immaculate, many of the panels have been replaced to make reading the names easier. Don’t forget to visit the ramparts above the memorial as the lawn was covered in thousands of poppies with very moving tributes to family members

We visited the Menin Gate as part of a tour group. Our time there was independent. The town of Ypres was lovely and the Museum very good. We were advised to arrive early. We did and it is good advice as viewing was a problem. The downside is the standing and waiting. Children

We have visited the Menin Gate quite a few times and it always chokes me up that the Belgians halt the traffic every night and play the last post in grateful memory of all the poor souls who lost their lives during World War 1. It was particularly poignant this time as it was

visited here a few times but never on the 11th. It was extremely busy with people of all ages and nationality attending to remember the fallen. I cannot stress how moving a tribute it is to see the town carry out the last post every evening at 8pm. I believe the service in the
Really enjoyed our first visit to Menin Gate as part of 100 year commemorations. Beautiful memorial,=. Moving to see the names of so many from many countries who lost their lives
Everyone should visit at least once. If you are there at 8 pm you will be blessed with a rendition of the last post, a short memorial service.

The most moving yet inspirational experience walking with the servicemen women and veterans to the centenary memorial service at the Gate. This shoud be on every school curriculum. RIP those who fell and died that we may live free

Visited twice over the Armistice weekend marking a hundred years since the end of WW1. Witnessed the last post the eve before then the ceremony on Sunday 11th November. This is something everyone should do to understand the sacrifice made by a generation. Despite it being a busy
Amazing humbling place to visit. Beautiful city. Square has many bars and cafes. Lots of little shops. Well worth a visit

Visited as a group of ex servicemen. Every night at 20.00hrs the play the last post, we have all been on parades and heard this countless times. This time it moved EVERYONE of us, even the Marine amongst us (supposedly the toughest of the lot) had a tear in his eye, as did I.
Large memorial which is in Ypres dedicated to the Unknown brave soldiers who died in the war,in the help for peace.The last post is played at 8 pm every night.Well worth a visit.

Amazing place,busy as a thoroughfare during the day and cordoned off for the evening ceremony each evening,where you are transported to a place of peace and salutation.To say it is moving and humbling is an understatement.Should be on every world weary individual`s bucket

For all those who have lost relatives in any conflict this is the place to go and reflect on what these brave people have done for us. There are no words that can tell of the feelings and emotions you get by being here. Certainly a experience not to be forgotten.

Have visited numerous before and been overwhelmed by the sheer number of names remembered here. However our visit on 11/11/18 was because of the discovery that my wife's G.G.Grandfather was commemorated here and made this a special and emotional visit.

Very powerful...if you are in the area you must see. Australia just donate 2 lion statues which are replicas of the original statues this month. It was interesting to see them and read about that. Also, all of the names are moving.
What an amazing monument, it took my breath away, so magnificent, difficult to absorb the reality of so many lives lost 100 years ago. May they rest in peace xx
The nightly ceremony marking the terrible sacrifice is humbling and moving. This is a must visit place and should be included in all school curriculums. An honour to attend.

On 11-11-18 we were honoured to have taken part in the 11-11-18 100 years service at the Menin Gate. The parade from the town square to the Menin Gate Memorial was huge and impressive to be part of. The service was emotional to see, especially when they release the poppy
Our first visit to the Menin Gate, and most definitely not our last. Deeply moving, a wonderful tribute to fallen heros.
We came for the remembrance day parade, the centenary, it was so touching and I was very glad to be able to see it.

A very moving place. A 'must visit' monument. All the names of the fallen are engaved inside the monument.

The Ypres Lions (copies) have now been returned outside gate entrance - gift from Australia. This memorial provides a sobering reminder of the horrific nature of war and community & personal sacrifice.
If you are in Ypres it is important to make time to visit the menin gate at 8 pm when the last post is played.
Very sombre yet well managed event. Last post, 2 mins silence, quire, piper and March past. Deeply moving. Must see if in Ypres.

Very moving, will go again and would recommend visiting, it was very busy, but nice that so many people wanted to pay their respects.

Just brings it all home to you seeing all those names on the walls and the multitude of wreaths laid on the steps. Worth a visit.

This has to be seen to be believed. So many lost lives remembered. The memorial is open all day but try and attend the Last Post ceremony which takes place at 2000 every night.

Been as a student, teacher and with friends. Nevers ceases to move me. Worth a visit every time as it is a poignant reminder of the fallen.

Very moving, a must for all who visit Ypres, during the day you can see all the names of those this monument honours and walk the ramparts, at night the last Post ceremony at Menin takes place, it is a sight to behold....

A must see! Awesome tribute to the fallen. Great place to realize the price of freedom. Bring your kids, history is alive here. Stay for the ceremony at 8pm every night.

As with all these memorials the the men with no known grave, it is very thought provoking. A must see site.

Wow what can I say unbelievable place packed every night with people from all over the world showing their respect to the fallen and unknown soldiers last post played ,could here a pin dropped hope to go back one day loads of bars shops restaurants leading up to it .if you time

Went to Belgium for weekend and travelled to ypes for last post. It was very moving we had six buglers a piper and choir very lucky. I'd recommend everybody to go and pay their respects but get there early has it gets crowed.

We spent a couple of days in Ypres. A must while you sre there is the Menin Gate. Every evening at 8 they play the Last Post. We got there just after 7 and managed to get a place at the front. It quickly filled up. The ceremony is very humbling and thought provoking. It was

An impressive memorial to the courageous people who lost their lives during world war one. Some good information points that show the significance of this part of the city.

This is an impressive structure that commerates the names of soldiers who died. The emotion of finding a family member name cannot be dscribed.

A magnificent tribute to those lost lives in WW1. The ceremony at 8pm every evening must not be missed.

A must to visit if you have any interest in the history of 20th century and the people from round the world who sacrificed their lives to try to end tyranny The sadness that they didn’t succeed and further on going conflicts is a sobering thought as you read the countless names

Visited the memorial and attended the Last Post Ceremony. Very thought provoking, sobering and emotional. Something everyone should do before you can fully appreciate the sacrifices made.

A real touching ceremony, does not last long but well worth attending. As a serving member of the Armed Forces it was truest amazing. Enough said

The last post ceremony and the sheer amout of names is amazing to see. A strong experience and recommended for people 13+ to get a full experience.

Absolutely Beautiful loved Ypres so much. Last post was a very respectful event and honour the all the soldiers and families.

Beautiful cathedrals and a Christmas market along with the poppy field (not real ones), you experience so much …

text.wiki:
Lille ( LEEL; French: [lil] (listen); Dutch: Rijsel [ˈrɛisəl]; Picard: Lile; West Flemish: Rysel) is a city at the northern tip of France, in French Flanders. On the Deûle River, near France's border with Belgium, it is the capital of the Hauts-de-France region, the prefecture of the Nord department, and the main city of the Métropole Européenne de Lille.
As of 2017, Lille had a population of 232,787 within its administrative limits, and Lille is the first city of the Métropole Européenne de Lille with a population of 1,146,320, making it the fourth-largest urban area in France after Paris, Lyon, and Marseille.


== History ==


=== Origins ===
Archeological digs seem to show the area as inhabited by as early as 2000 BC, most notably in the modern quartiers of Fives, Wazemmes and Vieux Lille. The original inhabitants of the region were the Gauls, such as the Menapians, the Morins, the Atrebates and the Nervians, who were followed by Germanic peoples: the Saxons, the Frisians and the Franks.
The legend of "Lydéric and Phinaert" puts the foundation of the city of Lille at 640. In the 8th century, the language of Old Low Franconian was spoken, as attested by toponymic research. Lille's Dutch name is Rijsel, which comes from ter ijsel (at the island) from Middle Dutch ijssel (“small island, islet”), calque of Old French l'Isle (“the Island”), itself from Latin Īnsula, from īnsula (“island”).
From 830 to around 910, the Vikings invaded Flanders. After the destruction caused by Normans' and the Magyars' invasion, the eastern part of the region was ruled by various local princes.
The first mention of the town dates from 1066: apud Insulam (Latin for "at the island"). It was then controlled by the County of Flanders, as were the regional cities (the Roman cities Boulogne, Arras, Cambrai as well as the Carolingian cities Valenciennes, Saint-Omer, Ghent and Bruges). The County of Flanders thus extended to the left bank of the Scheldt, one of the richest and most prosperous regions of Europe.


=== Middle Ages ===
The Carolingian duke Évrard lived in the city in the 9th century and participated in many of the day's political and military affairs. There was an important Battle of Lille in 1054.
From the 12th century, the fame of the Lille cloth fair began to grow. In 1144 Saint-Sauveur parish was formed, which would give its name to the modern-day quartier Saint-Sauveur.
The counts of Flanders, Boulogne, and Hainaut came together with England and East Frankia and tried to regain territory taken by Philip II of France following Henry II of England's death, a war that ended with the French victory at Bouvines in 1214. Infante Ferdinand, Count of Flanders was imprisoned and the county fell into dispute: it would be his wife, Jeanne, Countess of Flanders and Constantinople, who ruled the city. She was said to be well loved by the residents of Lille, who by that time numbered 10,000.
In 1225, the street performer and juggler Bertrand Cordel, doubtlessly encouraged by local lords, tried to pass himself off as Baldwin I of Constantinople (the father of Jeanne of Flanders), who had disappeared at the battle of Adrianople. He pushed the counties of Flanders and Hainaut towards sedition against Jeanne in order to recover his land. She called her cousin, Louis VIII ("The Lion"). He unmasked the imposter, whom Countess Jeanne quickly had hanged. In 1226 the king agreed to free Infante Ferdinand, Count of Flanders. Count Ferrand died in 1233, and his daughter Marie soon after. In 1235, Jeanne granted a city charter by which city governors would be chosen each All Saint's Day by four commissioners chosen by the ruler. On 6 February 1236, she founded the Countess's Hospital (Hospice Comtesse), which remains one of the most beautiful buildings in Old Lille. It was in her honour that the hospital of the Regional Medical University of Lille was named "Jeanne of Flanders Hospital" in the 20th century.
The Countess died in 1244 in the Abbey of Marquette, leaving no heirs. The rule of Flanders and Hainaut thus fell to her sister, Margaret II, Countess of Flanders, then to Margaret's son, Guy of Dampierre. Lille fell under the rule of France from 1304 to 1369, after the Franco-Flemish War (1297-1305).
The county of Flanders fell to the Duchy of Burgundy next, after the 1369 marriage of Margaret III, Countess of Flanders, and Philip the Bold, Duke of Burgundy. Lille thus became one of the three capitals of said Duchy, along with Brussels and Dijon. By 1445, Lille counted some 25,000 residents. Philip the Good, Duke of Burgundy, was even more powerful than the King of France, and made Lille an administrative and financial capital.
On 17 February 1454, one year after the taking of Constantinople by the Turks, Philip the Good organised a Pantagruelian banquet at his Lille palace, the still-celebrated "Feast of the Pheasant". There the Duke and his court undertook an oath to Christianity.
In 1477, at the death of the last duke of Burgundy, Charles the Bold, Mary of Burgundy married Maximilian of Austria, who thus became Count of Flanders.


=== Early modern era ===

The 16th and the 17th centuries were marked by a boom in the regional textile industry, the Protestant revolts and outbreaks of the plague.
Lille came under the rule of the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V in 1519. The Low Countries fell to his eldest son, Philip II of Spain, in 1555. The city remained under Spanish Habsburg rule until 1668.
Calvinism first appeared in the area in 1542, and by 1555, the authorities were taking steps to suppress that form of Protestantism. In 1566, the countryside around Lille was affected by the Iconoclastic Fury. In 1578, the Hurlus, a group of Protestant rebels, stormed the castle of the Counts of Mouscron. They were removed four months later by a Catholic Wallon regiment, and they tried several times between 1581 and 1582 to take the city of Lille, all in vain. The Hurlus were notably held back by the legendary Jeanne Maillotte. At the same time (1581), at the call of Elizabeth I of England, the north of the Seventeen Provinces, having gained a Protestant majority, successfully revolted and formed the Dutch Republic. The war brought or exacerbated periods of famine and plague (the last in 1667–1679).The first printer to set up shop in Lille was Antoine Tack in 1594. The 17th century saw the building of new institutions: an Irish College in 1610, a Jesuit college in 1611, an Augustinian college in 1622, almshouses or hospitals such as the Maison des Vieux hommes in 1624 and the Bonne et Forte Maison des Pauvres in 1661, and of a Mont-de-piété in 1626.Unsuccessful French attacks on the city were launched in 1641 and 1645. In 1667, Louis XIV of France (the Sun King) successfully laid siege to Lille, resulting in it becoming French in 1668 under the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle, provoking discontent among the citizens of the prosperous city. A number of important public works undertaken between 1667 and 1670, such as the Citadel (erected by Vauban), or the creation of the quartiers of Saint-André and la Madeleine, enabled the French king to gradually gain the confidence of his new subjects in Lille, some of whom continued to feel Flemish, but they had always spoken the Romance Picard language.

For five years, from 1708 to 1713, the city was occupied by the Dutch during the War of the Spanish Succession. Throughout the 18th century, Lille remained profoundly Catholic. It took little part in the French Revolution, but there were riots and the destruction of churches. In 1790, the city held its first municipal elections.


=== Post-French Revolution ===
In 1792, in the aftermath of the French Revolution, the Austrians, then in the United Provinces, laid siege to Lille. The "Column of the Goddess", erected in 1842 in the "Grand-Place" (officially named Place du Général-de-Gaulle), is a tribute to the city's resistance, led by Mayor François André-Bonte. Although Austrian artillery destroyed many houses and the main church of the city, the city did not surrender, and the Austrian Army left after eight days.

The city continued to grow and, by 1800, had some 53,000 residents, leading to Lille becoming the seat of the Nord départment in 1804. In 1846, a railway connecting Paris and Lille was built. In the early the 19th century, Napoleon I's continental blockade against the United Kingdom led to Lille's textile industry developing even more fully. The city was known for its cotton while the nearby towns of Roubaix and Tourcoing worked wool.  Leisure activities were thoroughly organised in 1858 for the 80,000 inhabitants.  Cabarets or taverns for the working class numbered 1,300, or one for every three houses. At that time the city counted 63 drinking and singing clubs, 37 clubs for card players, 23 for bowling, 13 for skittles, and 18 for archery. The churches likewise have their social organizations. Each club had a long roster of officers, and a busy schedule of banquets festivals and competitions. In 1853, Alexandre Desrousseaux composed his lullaby P'tit quinquin.
In 1858, Lille annexed the adjacent towns of Fives, Wazemmes, and Moulins. Lille's population was 158,000 in 1872, growing to over 200,000 by 1891. In 1896 Lille became the first city in France to be led by a socialist, Gustave Delory.
By 1912, Lille's population stood at 217,000. The city profited from the Industrial Revolution, particularly via coal and the steam engine. The entire region grew wealthy thanks to its mines and textile industry.


=== First World War ===

Lille's occupation by the Germans began on 13 October 1914 after a ten-day siege and heavy shelling, which destroyed 882 apartment and office blocks and 1,500 houses, mostly around the railway station and in the centre. By the end of October, the city was being run by German authorities.
Because Lille was only 20 km from the battlefield, German troops passed through the city regularly on their way to and from the front. As a result, occupied Lille became a place for the hospitalisation and the treatment of wounded soldiers as well as a place for soldiers' relaxation and entertainment. Many buildings, homes and businesses were requisitioned to those ends.Lille was liberated by the Allies on 17 October 1918, when General Sir William Birdwood and his troops were welcomed by joyous crowds. The general was made an honorary citizen of the city of Lille on 28 October.
The only audio recording known to have been made during World War I was recorded near Lille in October 1918. The two-minute recording captured the Royal Garrison Artillery conducting a gas shell bombardment.Lille was also the hunting ground of the German World War I flying ace Max Immelmann, who was nicknamed "the Eagle of Lille".


=== Années Folles, Great Depression and Popular Front ===

In July 1921, at the Pasteur Institute in Lille, Albert Calmette and Camille Guérin discovered the first anti-tuberculosis vaccine, known as BCG ("Bacille de Calmette et Guérin"). The Opéra de Lille, designed by Lille architect Louis M. Cordonnier, was dedicated in 1923.
From 1931, Lille felt the repercussions of the Great Depression, and by 1935, a third of the city's population lived in poverty. In 1936, the city's mayor, Roger Salengro, became Minister of the Interior of the Popular Front but eventually killed himself after right-wing groups led a slanderous campaign against him.


=== Second World War ===

During the Battle of France, Lille was besieged by German forces for several days. When Belgium was invaded, the citizens of Lille, still haunted by the events of World War I, began to flee the city in large numbers. Lille was part of the zone under control of the German commander in Brussels, and was never controlled by the Vichy government in France. Lille was instead controlled under the military administration in Northern France. The départments of Nord and Pas-de-Calais (with the exception of the coast, notably Dunkirk) were for the most part liberated from 1 to 5 September 1944, by British, Canadian and Polish troops. On 3 September, German troops began to leave Lille out of fear of the British, who were on their way from Brussels. The city was liberated by a British force consisting largely of tanks.Rationing came to an end in 1947, and by 1948, normality had returned to Lille.


=== Postwar ===

In 1967, the Chambers of Commerce of Lille, Roubaix and Tourcoing were joined, and in 1969< the Communauté urbaine de Lille (Lille urban community) was created, linking 87 communes with Lille.
Throughout the 1960s and the 1970s, the region was faced with some problems after the decline of the coal, mining and textile industries. From the early 1980s, the city began to turn itself more towards the service sector.
In 1983, the VAL, the world's first automated rapid transit underground network, opened. In 1993, a high-speed TGV train line was opened connecting Paris with Lille in one hour. This, with the opening of the Channel Tunnel in 1994 and the arrival of the Eurostar train put Lille at the centre of a triangle connecting Paris, London and Brussels.
Work on Euralille, an urban remodelling project, began in 1991. The Euralille Centre was opened in 1994, and the remodeled district is now full of parks and modern buildings containing offices, shops and apartments. In 1994 the "Grand Palais" was also opened for the general public, which is free for the public to enter on the first Sunday of every month.
Lille was chosen as European Capital of Culture in 2004, along with the Italian city of Genoa.
Lille and Roubaix were affected by the 2005 riots, like all of France's other urban centres.
In 2007 and again in 2010, Lille was awarded the label "Internet City".


== Climate ==
Lille can be described as having a temperate oceanic climate; summers normally do not reach high average temperatures, but winters can fall below freezing temperatures, but with averages quite a bit above the freezing mark. Precipitation is plentiful year round.
The table below gives average temperatures and precipitation levels for the 1981-2010 reference period.


== Environment ==
Lille is noted for its air pollution, with a 2018 study attributing 1,700 deaths per year in the agglomeration of Lille to pollution. In 2018, Lille held France's record pollution peaks.


== Economy ==

A former major mechanical, food industry and textile manufacturing centre as well as a retail and finance center, Lille is the largest city of a conurbation, built like a network of cities: Lille, Roubaix, Tourcoing and Villeneuve d'Ascq. The conurbation forms the Métropole Européenne de Lille which is France's fourth-largest urban conglomeration with a 2016 population of over 1.15 million.


=== Revenues and taxes ===
For centuries, Lille, a city of merchants, has displayed a wide range of incomes: great wealth and poverty have lived side by side, especially until the end of the 1800s. This contrast was noted by Victor Hugo in 1851 in his poem Les Châtiments:  « Caves de Lille ! on meurt sous vos plafonds de pierre ! » ("Cellars of Lille! We die under your stone ceilings!")


=== Employment ===
Employment in Lille has switched over half a century from a predominant industry to tertiary activities and services.
Services account for 91% of employment in 2006.

Employment in Lille-Hellemmes-Lomme from 1968 to 2006

Employment per categories in 1968 and in 2006

=== Enterprises ===
In 2007, Lille hosts around 21,000 industry or service sites.

Enterprises as per 31 December 2007


== Main sights ==
Lille features an array of architectural styles with various amounts of Flemish influence, including the use of brown and red brick. In addition, many residential neighborhoods, especially in Greater Lille, consist of attached 2–3 story houses aligned in a row, with narrow gardens in the back. These architectural attributes, many uncommon in France, help make Lille a transition in France to neighboring Belgium, as well as nearby Netherlands and England, where the presence of brick, as well as row houses or the terraced house is much more prominent.
Points of interest include

Lille Cathedral (Basilique-cathédrale Notre-Dame-de-la-Treille)
Citadel of Lille
Palais des Beaux-Arts de Lille
Jardin botanique de la Faculté de Pharmacie
Jardin botanique Nicolas Boulay
Jardin des Plantes de Lille


=== La Braderie ===

Lille hosts an annual braderie on the first weekend in September. Its origins are thought to date back to the twelfth century and between two and three million visitors are drawn into the city. It is one of the largest gatherings of France and the largest flea market in Europe.
Many of the roads in the inner city (including much of the old town) are closed and local shops, residents and traders set up stalls in the street.

== Transport ==


=== Public transport ===

The Métropole Européenne de Lille has a mixed mode public transport system, which is considered one of the most modern in the whole of France. It comprises buses, trams and a driverless light metro system, all of which are operated under the Transpole name. The Lille Metro is a VAL system (véhicule automatique léger = light automated vehicle) that opened on 16 May 1983, becoming the first automatic light metro line in the world. The system has two lines, with a total length of 45 kilometres (28 miles) and 60 stations. The tram system consists of two interurban tram lines, connecting central Lille to the nearby communities of Roubaix and Tourcoing, and has 45 stops. 68 urban bus routes cover the metropolis, 8 of which reach into Belgium.


=== Railways ===

Lille is an important crossroads in the European high-speed rail network. It lies on the Eurostar line to London (1:20 hour journey). The French TGV network also puts it only 1 hour from Paris, 38 minutes from Brussels, and connects to other major centres in France such as Marseille, Lyon, and Toulouse. Lille has two railway stations, which stand next door to one another: Lille-Europe station (Gare de Lille-Europe), which primarily serves high-speed trains and international services (Eurostar), and Lille-Flandres station (Gare de Lille-Flandres), which primarily serves lower speed regional trains and regional Belgian trains.


=== Highways ===

Five autoroutes pass by Lille, the densest confluence of highways in France after Paris:

Autoroute A27 : Lille – Tournai – Brussels / Liège – Germany
Autoroute A23 : Lille – Valenciennes
Autoroute A1  : Lille – Arras – Paris / Reims – Lyon / Orléans / Le Havre
Autoroute A25 : Lille – Dunkirk – Calais – England / North Belgium
Autoroute A22 : Lille – Antwerp – NetherlandsA sixth one – the proposed A24 – will link Amiens to Lille if built, but there is opposition to its route.


=== Air traffic ===
Lille Lesquin International Airport is 15 minutes from the city centre by car (11 km). In terms of shipping, it ranks fourth, with almost 38,000 tonnes of freight which pass through each year. Its passenger traffic, around 1.2 million in 2010, is modest due to the proximity to Brussels, Charleroi, and Paris-CDG airports. The airport mostly connects other French and European cities (some with low-cost airlines).


=== Waterways ===

Lille is the third-largest French river port after Paris and Strasbourg. The river Deûle is connected to regional waterways with over 680 km (423 mi) of navigable waters. The Deûle connects to Northern Europe via the River Scarpe and the River Scheldt (towards Belgium and the Netherlands), and internationally via the Lys River (to Dunkerque and Calais).
Shipping statistics


== Education ==
With over 110,000 students, the metropolitan area of Lille is one of France's top student cities.

With roots back from 1562 to 1793 as University of Douai, (then as Université Impériale in 1808), the State University of Lille was established in Lille in 1854 with Louis Pasteur as the first dean of its Faculty of Sciences. A school of medicine and an engineering school were also established in Lille in 1854; and the University of Lille was united as the association of existing public Faculties in 1896. It was then split into three independent university campuses in 1970: Lille 1 University of Science and Technology, Lille 2 University of Law and Health, and Lille 3 Charles de Gaulle University of Humanities, Social sciences, Literature and Arts.At the beginning of 2018, Lille 1, Lille 2 and Lille 3 merged to form the new University of Lille (student enrollment: 70,000).
It is part of the Community of Universities and Institutions (COMUE) Lille Nord de France and the European Doctoral College Lille Nord de France.

The Arts et Métiers ParisTech, an engineering graduate school of industrial and mechanical engineering, settled in Lille in 1900. This campus is one of the eight Teaching and Research Center (CER) of the school. Its creation was decided by Pierre-Nicolas Legrand de Lérant.
Ecole Centrale de Lille is one of the five Centrale Graduate Schools of engineering in France; it was founded in Lille city in 1854, its graduate engineering education and research center was established as Institut industriel du Nord (IDN) in 1872, in 1968 it moved in a modern campus in Lille suburb.
École nationale supérieure de chimie de Lille was established as Institut de chimie de Lille in 1894 supporting chemistry research as followers of Kuhlmann's breakthrough works in Lille.
École supérieure de journalisme de Lille, journalism school created in 1924.
Skema Business School established in 1892 is ranked among the top business schools in France.
École pour l'informatique et les nouvelles technologies settled in Lille in 2009.
ESME-Sudria and E-Artsup settled in Lille in 2012.
The ESA – École Supérieure des Affaires is a Business Management school established in Lille in 1990.
IEP Sciences-Po Lille political studies institute was established in Lille in 1992.
The Institut supérieur européen de formation par l'action is also located in Lille.
The Institut supérieur européen de gestion group (ISEG Group) established in Lille in 1988.
The European Doctoral College Lille Nord de France is headquartered in Lille Metropolis and includes 3,000 PhD Doctorate students supported by university research laboratories.
The Université Catholique de Lille was founded in 1875. Today it has law, economics, medicine, physics faculties and schools. Among the most famous is Institut catholique d'arts et métiers (ICAM) founded in 1898, ranked 20th among engineering schools, with the specificity of graduating polyvalent engineers, Ecole des Hautes études d'ingénieur (HEI) a school of engineering founded in 1885 and offering 10 fields of specialization, École des hautes études commerciales du nord (EDHEC) founded in 1906, IESEG School of Management founded in 1964 (17th place in the latest Financial Times global ranking of the 90 best masters in management, published on Monday 12 September 2016).  and Skema Business School currently ranked within the top 5, the top 10 and top 15 business schools in France, respectively. In 1924 ESJ – a leading journalism school – was established.

== Media and sports ==
Local newspapers include Nord éclair and La Voix du Nord.
France's national public television network has a channel that focuses on the local area: France 3 Nord-Pas-de-Calais
The city's most major association football club, Lille OSC, currently plays in Ligue 1, the highest level of football in France. The club has won eight major national trophies and regularly features in the UEFA Champions League and UEFA Europa League. In the 2010–11 season, Lille won the league and cup double.
Lille's Stade Pierre-Mauroy was the playground for the final stages of the FIBA EuroBasket 2015.
It was in Lille that the 100th World Esperanto Congress took place, in 2015.
